revision.text:
[[File:Rassias Photo.jpg|thumb|John A. Rassias, professor and creator of the Rassias Method for Language instruction]] '''John Arthur Rassias''' (August 20, 1925 – December 2, 2015) was an American professor who developed a method for the teaching of foreign languages, the Rassias Method, also known as the Dartmouth Intensive Language Model.<ref name=":1" /> John Rassias founded the [[Dartmouth College's Rassias Center for World Languages and Cultures|Rassias Center for World Languages and Cultures]], a department of [[Dartmouth College]] situated in the Office of the Provost that works with language learners and professionals from around the world.
== Early life == John A. Rassias was born on August 20, 1925 to Athanathios and Eleni (Leonardakis) Rassias, immigrants from [[Georgitsi|Georgitsi, Greece]]. A [[World War II|WWII]] veteran, Rassias enlisted in the Marines and fought on [[Okinawa Island|Okinawa]]. Rassias later referred to his experience in the war as important to his understanding of how cultural and linguistic understanding connects people of varying backgrounds and experiences. As Rassias states in his upcoming book ''To Be Human, the Unzipped Mind:'' ''"I am born in Manchester, New Hampshire, to a Greek father and Greek mother. Then some buddies and I invade Okinawa. Then I become a teacher...The war has ended... As the Occupation wears on I come into contact with more and more Japanese. Suspicion and distrust give way gradually to the need to communicate and work with them. I roam over the destroyed city (Sasebo)…The desire to understand the Japanese eventually overcomes the hate we’ve absorbed in our training and in combat, it is displaced by the simple human response of sympathy for the afflicted. For the second time in my life, language becomes the arbiter between me and others. Emotion. Learning takes place there, for nothing is real unless it touches me and I embrace it."''<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://rassias.dartmouth.edu/john/|title=John Rassias|website=rassias.dartmouth.edu|access-date=2017-01-11}}</ref>
== Education == Rassias graduated summa cum laude from the [[University of Bridgeport]], and later obtained a doctorat d’Etat at the [[University of Dijon]], Dijon, France. He continued with further research at the [[Sorbonne]] and also studied at and performed with the Cours [[René Simon|Réné Simon]] in Paris in the 1950s. Rassias also received a certificate from the Institut de Phonétique in Paris and completed additional study at Laval University in Québec.
== Work == In 1964 John Rassias became a consultant for [[Peace Corps]] language education programs throughout the world. He also served as Director of the first pilot program of languages for the Peace Corps in Africa and as Director of Language Programs at Dartmouth. This work initiated his development of the Rassias teaching method.
From 1965 to 2015 Rassias was William R. Kenan Professor of French and Italian at [[Dartmouth College]], where the Rassias Center uses his method.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kenancharitabletrust.org/KCTAR2016.pdf|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rassias.dartmouth.edu/method/|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> At Dartmouth, he was the founder and director of Dartmouth’s Language Study Abroad (LSA) program, through which Dartmouth students may complete their language requirement in a foreign country.
Rassias "put the teacher in the role of the performer, acting out words and expressions in imaginary real-life settings and inculcating vocabulary and grammar through rapid-fire drills that gave students no time to think in English."<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/06/us/john-rassias-who-pioneered-foreign-language-teaching-dies-at-90.html|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> He believed that every class was to be treated like the first class, and for this reason gained appreciation from his students.
In 1978 Rassias was appointed to [[Jimmy Carter|President Jimmy Carter's]] Commission on Foreign Language and International Studies. In 1994, Rassias was appointed to the Commission of the Modern Language Association of America on the study of service in the profession. He was also elected to the Division of the Teaching of Literature of the [[Modern Language Association]] in 1995, which he chaired in 1998. In addition, Rassias served as a member of the Advisory Committee on Foreign Languages to the Connecticut State Board of Education.
In 1998, Rassias was appointed as head of a commission focused on preserving the Greek language among Americans of Greek heritage by the Archbishop of the [[Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America]].
In 2006, Rassias participated of the creation of a March 2007 pilot program for Intensive English (IE) education outside of [[Mexico City]]. This pilot program became called the Inter-American Partnership for Education, which remains active today.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://worldfund.org/en/programs/iape.html|title=IAPE - Worldfund|last=Hickner|first=Lena|website=worldfund.org|access-date=2017-01-11}}</ref>
== The Rassias Method == The method aims to "make the participant feel comfortable and natural with the language in a short period of time" and involves "teaching procedures and dramatic techniques which seek to eliminate inhibitions and create an atmosphere of free expression from the very first day of class".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rassias.dartmouth.edu/method/|title=The Method|website=rassias.dartmouth.edu|access-date=2017-01-11}}</ref>
The emphasis of the Rassias Method is spoken language. Drill techniques are quick-paced and stress theatrical elements as well as immediate positive reinforcement and error correction.
== Personal life == Rassias was married to Mary Ann Evanstock (1928-2012) from 1954 to 2012 and had three children, nine grandchildren and one great-grandchild.
== Awards, Honors and Distinctions == John Rassias received many awards for his work in language education, including the following: * First Arthur Wilson Outstanding Teacher Award at Dartmouth (1968) * E. Harris Harbison Award for Gifted Teaching by the [[Danforth Foundation]] (1971) * Endowed Chair, William R. Kenan Professor (1977) * Dartmouth College's Inaugural President's Medal for Outstanding Leadership and Achievement in 1991. * Robert A. Fish Memorial Prize in Outstanding Teaching awarded by the Dean of the Faculty at Dartmouth College (1997) * Dartmouth Class of 2008 Distinguished Teaching Award (2008) Rassias received eight honorary degrees from the following: * [[University of Bridgeport]] (Connecticut), * [[Alma College]] (Michigan), * [[Washington University in St. Louis|Washington University]] (Missouri), * [[Plymouth State University|Plymouth State College]] (New Hampshire), * [[University of Detroit Mercy|University of Detroit]] (Michigan), * [[Hampden–Sydney College|Hampden-Sydney]] (Virginia) * [[Moravian College]] (Pennsylvania) * [[Pine Manor College]] (Massachusetts)
== Legacy == Rassias died in [[Norwich, Vermont]] on December 2, 2015 at the age of 90.<ref name=":0" /> The [[Rassias Center]], run by Rassias’ daughter, Helene Rassias-Miles, continues to provide language education to Dartmouth community members and learners all over the world. Dartmouth undergraduates continue to receive language instruction through the Rassias Method.
Throughout his career Rassias reached a large number of students and educators around the world. Archives suggest that to date, his work has affected more than 200,000 Peace Corps volunteers since 1964 and continues to be fundamental in that organization’s language instruction approach.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://peacecorpsonline.org/messages/messages/2629/1011783.html|title=Peace Corps Online: February 10, 2003 - The Rassias Foundation: John A. Rassias honored by Peace Corps for developing innovative and highly effective approach to teaching languages|website=peacecorpsonline.org|access-date=2017-02-01}}</ref> An innovative language curriculum designer, Rassias started, in the early 1980s, immersion language programs for continuing education purposes. These highly efficient 10-day summer programs have enabled adult language learners to make significant gains in their command of the oral and written foreign language in a short period of time. Some rank beginners have even been able to reach the Intermediate-Low level (ACTFL scale) during the program, an achievement which usually requires three to four semesters in college curricula.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.faculty.fairfield.edu/jgoldfield/TenYearsofSpeaking.pdf|title=Ten Years of Speaking to Learn: The Assistant Teacher Program at Fairfield University|last=Goldfield|first=Joel|date=2013|website=http://www.faculty.fairfield.edu|publisher=|access-date=2/1/2017}}</ref> At Dartmouth and other U.S. post-secondary institutions, the Rassias Method has been used to teach more than 25,000 students in language acquisition courses. Through the Inter-American Partnership for Education (IAPE) over 1.5 million students of all ages in Mexico have been impacted by faculty trained in the Rassias Method.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://worldfund.org/en/programs/iape.html|title=IAPE - Worldfund|last=Hickner|first=Lena|website=worldfund.org|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-02-01}}</ref> Finally, language learners worldwide continue to receive instruction in the method through workshops and classes offered through the Rassias Center.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *Anderson, Jon. "Cicero Cops On Crash Course." ''Chicago Tribune''. 17 December 1998. Web. <http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1998-12-17/news/9812170226_1_spanish-foreign-language-police>. *Baolin, Ma. "Teaching Languages by Using Theater." ''Beijing Review'' 30.29 (1987): 1-3. *Beall, Kathleen R. "John Rassias, Giving Life to Language Worldwide." ''ESL Magazine.'' June 2000. *Cormier, Raymond J. "Appreciating Rassias’ Method." ''Valley News'' [West Lebanon, NH] 14 August 2001. *Craig , William, Jr. . "This Teacher Runs on High-Test." ''Valley News'' [West Lebanon, NH] 3 September 1992. *Dotson-Renta, Lara N. "Humanizing the Humanities." ''The Atlantic'', 17 January 2016. Web. <https://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2016/01/humanizing-the-humanities/424470/>. *Fairbrothers, Gregg, and Catalina Gorla. "What is the Social Value of Learning a New Language?" ''Forbes''. 4 June 2012. Web. <https://www.forbes.com/sites/greggfairbrothers/2012/06/04/what-is-the-social-value-of-learning-a-new-language/#497d06c0230d>. *Hechinger, Fred M. "About Education - A Maverick Teacher Enlivens Students With Flair and Style." ''The New York Times''. 12 October 1980. *"Latest News from Worldfund." Worldfund. <https://worldfund.org/en/news/latest-news.html>. *{{cite news|title=Parlez-vous Francais? Oui, if you can survive|newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune|date=23 April 1978}} *Plenda, Melanie. "He Developed a Way to 'Dance' in a Foreign Language." ''New Hampshire News'' 6 March 2011. *Tedick, Diane J., and John W. Oller. "Methods That Work: Ideas for Literacy and Language Teachers." ''The Modern Language Journal'' 78.1 (1994): p 106. *Valdini, A., S. Early, C. Augart, G. D. Cleghorn, and H. C. R. Miles. "Spanish Language Immersion and Reinforcement During Residency: A Model for Rapid Acquisition of Competency." ''Teaching and Learning in Medicine'' 21.3 (2009): 261-66. {{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rassias, John}} [[Category:1925 births]] [[Category:2015 deaths]] [[Category:Dartmouth College faculty]] [[Category:University of Bridgeport alumni]] [[Category:Language teachers]] [[Category:American people of Greek descent]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} [[Image:Julius Reisinger.jpg|thumb|500px|right|Julius Reisinger, original choreographer of the ballet ''Swan Lake'' in 1877]] '''Vaclav (Wentsel), or Jules or Julius Wentsel Reisinger''' (1828 – 1892) is paradoxical figure in the history of [[ballet]]. This prolific [[choreographer]], an author of more than twenty works on various European stages, directed the [[Moscow]] company of the [[Bolshoi Theatre]]. He is linked with two memorable events: the first stage production of [[Tchaikovsky]]'s ballet ''[[Swan Lake]]'' and the production of the first ballet performance for the opening of the [[Prague National Theatre]] in 1884. His work on ''Swan Lake'' was considered unsuccessful by the critics of the day but not necessarily unsuccessful by the theatre-going public—after all, Reisinger's original production of ''Swan Lake'' was kept in the active repertoire of the [[Bolshoi Theatre]] for seven years and was performed over thirty times during a period when other ballets could not sustain even twenty performances. In fact, the production was not pulled until the scenery and costumes were worn and threadbare. Much of its popularity was assumably due to its beautiful musical score which was critically acclaimed even though the choreography was not.
Reisinger was born in February 1828 in [[Prague]] of a native [[Czechoslovakia|Czech]] family. He began his professional life as a dancer in the [[corps de ballet]], rising to the position of leading soloist. In 1850, he was the Czech partner of the famous dancer [[Lucille Grahn]] in ''[[La Esmeralda (ballet)|La Esmeralda]]'' (as Phoebus) and ''[[Giselle]]'' (as Hilarion). He also had success in the part of Diavolino in [[Jules Perrot]]'s ballet ''Catarina, ou La Fille du Bandit''. In short, the young dancer mastered the romantic repertoire and was familiar with the new ballet productions, one more fact in favour of Reisinger's erudition.
In 1852, he succeeded in securing an eight-year engagement on the [[Germany|German]] and [[Austria]]n stages. In 1860 he returned to his native Prague to the [[Nove Mesto Theatre]], already in the position of the choreographer. This was the first time a Czech theatre was actually headed by a Czech choreographer. [[Image:Swanlakedecor.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Original sketch design for the ballet ''Swan Lake'' in 1877]]
==Misconceptions== It is commonly thought that none of Reisinger's ballets was successful but facts contradict this. An example of this would be "Swan Lake". a Classical Ballet that is still being performed today. Why then was such a [[choreographer]] invited to brilliant [[Leipzig]] where he directed the ballet company from 1864 to 1872? Large-scale works were presented there, such as ''Saltarello'' and ''Interrupted Solitude'' to the music of the [[Leipzig]] [[kapellmeister]], Muhldorfer. And from Leipzig, Reisinger was invited to [[Russia]].
Indications of Reisinger's [[Moscow]] endeavors are readily found in the writings of several [[Russia]]n historians, the first one being a staging of the five-act ballet ''The Crystal Slipper'' (1871, a ballet of the ''[[Cinderella]]'' story) to Muhldorfer's music, which Yuri Bakhrushin referring to original sources, notes as quite successful. In 1873, finding himself in the post of '''Director of the Moscow Ballet''', he created successive multiple-act productions such as ''Kastchei'', where, as confirmed again by Yuri Bakhrushin, the choreographer successfully developed the Russian theme. He also produced ''Stella'' and ''Ariadne'' (in tandem with Imperial Balletmaster [[Marius Petipa]]). All ballets (except ''Kastchei'', which he staged with the two [[composer]]s Muhldorfer and Gerber) used the music of Gerber. At the same time, in the last two (''Stella'' and ''Ariadne''), Reisinger reworked elements of ancient art according to the dictates of [[Biedermeier]]. Added to that, in the production of ''Ariadne'', the Theatre Directorate allotted what was (for that time), the very large sum of 40,000 [[Russian ruble|roubles]]. This not only suggests the confidence they had invested in Reisinger, but also confirms that in his first two years in Russia he had clearly won the authority of the Imperial Theatre Directorate. It was with this artistic background that the choreographer approached the first production of ''[[Swan Lake]]''.
==Questions Remain== Though today Reisinger is considered the father of Czech professional ballet, criticisms regarding his choreography (such as "mediocre," "ordinary," and "untalented") have followed him, even after his death. His [[critics]] did not endow him with the usual praise in his own country or in Russia, but this did not prevent him from having a very long balletic career. With this in mind, one must ask oneself: was this choreographer truly untalented? Is it possible that in [[Prague]], [[Moscow]], [[Leipzig]] and [[Berlin]] his ascent to the top was merely the result of a long-patient public and theatre administration? Though good timing undoubtedly played some part in his career, it is possibly unrealistic to form the conclusion that this was the only factor in his solid rise to the forefront of the most respected theatres of the time.
{{Portal|Ballet}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Reisinger, Julius}} [[Category:Ballet choreographers]] [[Category:Ballet masters]] [[Category:Russian ballet]] [[Category:1828 births]] [[Category:1892 deaths]]

{{Infobox musical artist |name = Kaila Mullady |image = |image_size = |caption = |background = solo_singer |Website = https://kailamullady.com/ |birth_name = |alias = |birth_date = |birth_place = [[New York City]] |origin = [[New York City]] |genre = *[[Indie Rock]] *[[Beatrhyming]] *[[Vocal Music]] *[[Improvisation]] |occupation = *[[Beatrhyming|Beatrhymer]], *[[singer-songwriter]] *[[Beatboxer]] *[[Multi-instrumentalist]] *[[Actress]] |instrument = *[[Beatrhyming]] *[[Beatboxing]] *[[Vocals]] *[[Guitar]] *[[Saxophone]] |years_active = |label = |associated_acts = [[Kid Lucky]], [[Beatbox House]], [[Soul Inscribed]], [[Gene Shinozaki]] |website = }} '''Kaila Mullady''' is an American [[Beatboxer]], [[Beatrhyming|Beatrhymer]], Musician, Actress, and <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/future_tense/2014/02/21/whatsapp_helps_beatboxers_kaila_mullady_alem_and_bmg_share_beats.html|title=This Might Be the Most Surprising Use of WhatsApp|first=Ben|last=Mirin|date=21 February 2014|publisher=|accessdate=15 August 2017|via=Slate}}</ref> the 2015 female beatbox world champion.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://harrytv.com/video_clips/world-beatboxing-champion-kaila-mullady/|title=World Beatboxing Champion Kaila Mullady – HARRY|publisher=|accessdate=14 August 2017}}</ref> She is a former member of the [[Beatbox House]] collective.
==Musical Style== Mullady has a variety of musical acts as a solo artist. She has a distinct style of beatboxing, which consists of polyrhythms, avant garde style compositions, incorporation of theatrical performance, the [[Mouth trumpet]] technique and extensive [[beatrhyming]]. She is also noted for her [[one woman band]] performances, which incorporate singing, [[beatboxing]], guitar, rapping, and [[live looping]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://laughingsquid.com/new-yorker-kaila-mullady-named-the-world-female-beatbox-champion-at-the-2015-beatbox-battle-world-championships/|title=New Yorker Kaila Mullady Named the World Female Beatbox Champion at the 2015 Beatbox Battle World Championships|date=31 July 2015|publisher=|accessdate=14 August 2017}}</ref>
==Early life== Mullady's interest in music and beatboxing began at a young age. She took up guitar at age ten and began beatboxing for parties when she got older.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geckosadventures.com/tales/beatbox-kaila-mullady/|title=Girl power: Meet American Vice Beatbox Champion, Kaila Mullady – Geckos Tales|date=2 March 2017|publisher=|accessdate=14 August 2017}}</ref> She originally planned on pursuing a career as a teacher, but over time became disinterested in teaching.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxygen.com/blogs/kaila-mullady-is-reinvigorating-beatboxing-and-schooling-the-boys-along-the-way|title=Kaila Mullady Is Reinvigorating Beatboxing And Schooling The Boys Along The Way|date=28 September 2016|publisher=|accessdate=14 August 2017}}</ref> In 2012 she met award-winning beatboxer J-Flo, and was introduced to the modern beatbox community. After an accident resulting in a broken back, which prevented her from performing, during her recovery, she met beatbox pioneer [[Kid Lucky]]. He introduced her to the art of [[beatrhyming]] which ultimately changed and defined the course of her artistry. He befriended Mullady and became her mentor and extensive collaborator.
==Career== Mullady is an active beatbox battler,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.motivationalmillennial.com/kailamullady/|title=44: Kaila Mullady|website=Motivational Millennial|accessdate=15 August 2017}}</ref> whose championship titles include<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/lifestyle/news/a43958/woman-beatboxing-will-blow-your-mind/|title=This Woman's Beatboxing Skills Will Totally Blow Your Mind|date=28 July 2015|publisher=|accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref> [[Beatbox Battle World Championship|2015 world female beatbox champion]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://laughingsquid.com/new-yorker-kaila-mullady-named-the-world-female-beatbox-champion-at-the-2015-beatbox-battle-world-championships/|title=New Yorker Kaila Mullady Named the World Female Beatbox Champion at the 2015 Beatbox Battle World Championships|date=31 July 2015|publisher=|accessdate=15 August 2017}}</ref> as well as three-time beatrhyming champion, three-time American [[loopstation]] champion and 2014 vice american champion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2226591/kaila-mullady-beatboxing/|title=This Woman’s Beatboxing Skills Give Cara Delevingne A Run For Her Money|publisher=|accessdate=14 August 2017}}</ref> She performs extensively as a member of groups like the american beatbox collective [[Beatbox House]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fuzion.com/artists/beatbox-house/|title=Beatboxer, Beatboxers, Beatbox House Beat Box House - Beat Boxer - Fuzion Entertainment - Fuzion.com|publisher=|accessdate=14 August 2017}}</ref> and the improv comedy, hip hop fusion troupe<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ravishly.com/worth-mention/watch-kaila-mullady-badass-beatboxing-lady|title=Watch: Kaila Mullady, The Badass Beatboxing Lady|publisher=|accessdate=15 August 2017}}</ref> "North coast".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.indyweek.com/indyweek/hip-hop-and-comedy-both-thrive-on-tight-timing/Content?oid=4335637|title=Hip-hop and comedy both thrive on tight timing|first=Eric|last=Tullis|publisher=|accessdate=14 August 2017}}</ref> She is head director of BEAT Global's Beat Rocker program, where she conceptualized a method of speech therapy which involves teaching beatboxing and beatrhyming as a method of developing speech articulation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aplus.com/a/Kaila-Mullady-beatboxing-video-swissbeatboxing?rel=homepage|title=There's No Stopping This World Beatbox Champion, And This Video Is Proof|date=29 July 2015|publisher=|accessdate=15 August 2017}}</ref> In this program she actively teaches beatboxing to blind and mentally handicapped youth.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://futureofstorytelling.org/speaker/b-e-a-t-featuring-kaila-mullady-and-y|title=B.E.A.T. Featuring Kaila Mullady and Y? – ,|website=futureofstorytelling.org|accessdate=14 August 2017}}</ref> She collaborates extensively with her mentor [[Kid Lucky]] as "The Adventures of Kaila and the Kid". They perform and teach workshops in the arts of beatrhyming and beatboxing nationwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://matadornetwork.com/nights/next-generation-beatboxers-blowing-around-world/|title=The next generation of beatboxers blowing up around the world|publisher=|accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref> She also collaborates extensively with her boyfriend, beatboxer, vocalist, musician and actor Mark Martin. They compete in beatbox tag team battles under the name "Power couple",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://markmartincreative.com/about/|title=Meet Mark Martin – Mark Martin|publisher=|accessdate=14 August 2017}}</ref> and perform as a musical duo under the name "Lightship". She has showcased her beatboxing and singing abilities in commercials for product brands such as <ref>{{cite web|url=http://naariedinger.squarespace.com/pop-matte/|title=Pop Matte|website=squarespace.com|accessdate=15 August 2017}}</ref> [[Clinique]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://carrot.is/case-studies/clinique-matte-makeover|title=Carrot Creative|first=Carrot Creative|last=LLC|website=carrot.is|accessdate=15 August 2017}}</ref> and [[Spoonflower]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.spoonflower.com/tag/kaila-mullady/|title=kaila mullady – Spoonflower Blog|website=blog.spoonflower.com|accessdate=15 August 2017}}</ref>

revision.text: {{for|the concept|Linguistic imperialism}} {{Infobox book | name = Linguistic Imperialism | image = Linguistic Imperialism.jpg| caption = | alt = | author = [[Robert Phillipson]] | title_orig = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[United Kingdom]] | series = | subject = [[Philosophy]], [[Outline of social science|social sciences]], [[language]], [[education]] | published = 1992 | media_type = | pages = 365 | awards = | isbn = 0194371468 | oclc = 30978070 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = Linguistic Imperialism Continued (2010) | wikisource = }} '''''Linguistic Imperialism''''' is a book written by [[Robert Phillipson]], research professor at [[Copenhagen Business School]]'s Department of English, published in 1992 by [[Oxford University Press]]. In ''Linguistic Imperialism'', Phillipson argues that [[Western world|Western countries]] have used [[English language|English]] as a tool of [[imperialism]] to dominate [[Colonialism|colonies and former colonies]]. He further explores the ideologies transmitted through the English language. The book was followed by ''Linguistic Imperialism Continued'', first published by [[Routledge]] in 2010.{{Cite journal |last=Waters |first=Alan |title=Linguistic Imperialism Continued |url=http://eltj.oxfordjournals.org/content/67/1/126.extract |journal=ELT }} ==See also== *[[Cultural imperialism]] *[[English as a lingua franca]] *[[Hegemony]] *[[Linguistic imperialism]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ;Sources {{Refbegin}} *{{Cite book |ref=harv |last=Phillipson |first=Robert |year=1992 |title=Linguistic Imperialism |location=Oxford |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn=0194371468 |oclc=30978070 }} *{{Cite book |ref=harv |last=Phillipson |first=Robert |year=2010 |title=Linguistic Imperialism Continued |location=New York |publisher=[[Routledge]] |isbn=9780415872010 |oclc=730949179 }} {{Refend}} [[Category:1992 books]] [[Category:Applied linguistics]] [[Category:Education books]] [[Category:English as a global language]] [[Category:Interlinguistics]] [[Category:Linguistic rights]] [[Category:Linguistics books]] [[Category:Imperialism]] [[Category:Social sciences books]] [[Category:Sociolinguistics works]] {{lang-book-stub}} {{sociolinguistics-stub}}

{{BLP sources|date=June 2012}}
{{Infobox person | name = Matthias Felleisen | image = Matthias Felleisen.jpg | alt = Photograph of Felleisen standing in front of a projector screen, gesturing | caption = Felleisen speaking at the [[Symposium on Principles of Programming Languages]] in [[Madrid, Spain]] in 2010 | birth_name = | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Birth-date and age|Month DD, YYYY}} --> | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|Month DD, YYYY|Month DD, YYYY}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Professor of [[computer science]] | alma_mater = | known_for = Founder of [[Racket (programming language)|PLT]] }}
'''Matthias Felleisen''' is a [[German-American]] [[computer science]] professor and author. He grew up in Germany and immigrated to the US when he was 21 years old.
Felleisen is currently a Trustee Professor in the [[Northeastern University College of Computer and Information Science|College of Computer and Information Science]] at [[Northeastern University, Boston|Northeastern University]] in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]]. In the past he has taught at [[Rice University]] after receiving his PhD from [[Indiana University]] under the direction of [[Daniel P. Friedman]].
Felleisen's interests include programming languages, including software tools, program design, the Design Recipe, software contracts, and many more.<ref name='self-website'>{{cite web|title=Research|accessdate=2012-06-26|url=http://www.ccs.neu.edu/home/matthias/research.html}}</ref> In the 1990s, Felleisen launched [[Racket (programming language)|PLT]] and TeachScheme! (now [[ProgramByDesign]]) with the goal of teaching program-design principles to beginners and to explore the use of [[Scheme (programming language)|Scheme]] to produce large systems. As part of this effort, he authored ''[[How to Design Programs]]'' ([[MIT Press]], 2001) with [[Robert Bruce Findler|Findler]], [[Matthew Flatt|Flatt]], and [[Shriram Krishnamurthi|Krishnamurthi]].
Control delimiters, the basis of [[delimited continuation]]s, were introduced by Felleisen<ref name='felleisen88'>{{cite journal|author=Matthias Felleisen|title=The theory and practice of first-class prompts|journal=[[Principles of Programming Languages]]|year=1988|doi=10.1145/73560.73576|pages=180–190|isbn=0-89791-252-7}}</ref> in 1988. They have since been used in a large number of domains, particularly in defining new [[Operator_(computer_programming)|control operator]]s; see Queinnec<ref name="queinnec survey">{{cite journal | author=Queinnec, Christian | publisher=[[École Polytechnique]] and [[INRIA]]-Rocquencourt | title=A library of high-level control operators | citeseerx = 10.1.1.29.4790 | date=April 1994}}</ref> for a survey.
[[A-normal form]] (ANF), an [[Intermediate language|intermediate representation]] of [[program (computer science)|program]]s in [[functional compiler]]s were introduced by Sabry and Felleisen in 1992<ref>{{cite conference | id = Sabry92 | first = Amr | last = Sabry |author2= Felleisen, Matthias | title = Reasoning about Programs in Continuation-Passing Style | booktitle = Proceedings of the 1992 ACM Conference on LISP and Functional Programming, LFP'92 | location = San Francisco, CA, US | url = http://www.cs.rice.edu/CS/PLT/Publications/Scheme/lfp92-sf.ps.gz | accessdate = 2012-11-16 }}</ref> as a simpler alternative to [[continuation-passing style]] (CPS).
Felleisen gave the keynote addresses at the 2011 [[Technical Symposium on Computer Science Education]], 2010 [[International Conference on Functional Programming]],<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2012-12-18|title=ICFP 2010 Homepage|url=http://www.icfpconference.org/icfp2010/}}</ref> 2004 [[European Conference on Object-Oriented Programming]] and the 2001 Symposium on [[Principles of Programming Languages]], and several other conferences and workshops on computer science.
In 2006, he was inducted as a [[fellow]] of the [[Association for Computing Machinery]]. In 2009, he received the Karl V. Karlstrom Outstanding Educator Award from the [[Association for Computing Machinery|ACM]].<ref name='karlstrom'>{{cite web|accessdate=2012-06-26|title=ACM Award Citation|url=http://awards.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2089571&srt=all&aw=142&ao=KARLSTRM&yr=2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504095940/http://awards.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2089571&srt=all&aw=142&ao=KARLSTRM&yr=2009|archivedate=2012-05-04|df=}}</ref> In 2010, he received the [https://web.archive.org/web/20130603133901/http://www.sigcse.org/programs/awards/outstanding SIGCSE Award for Outstanding Contribution to Computer Science Education] from the ACM. In 2012, he received the ACM SIGPLAN Programming Languages Achievement Award for "significant and lasting contribution to the field of programming languages"<ref name="sigplan-achievement">{{cite web|accessdate=2012-06-26|title=Programming Languages Achievement Award|url=http://www.sigplan.org/Awards/Achievement/2012}}</ref> including small-step operational semantics for control and state, mixin classes and mixin modules, a fully abstract semantics for Sequential PCF, web programming techniques, higher-order contracts with blame, and static typing for dynamic languages.
==Books== Felleisen is co-author of:
* ''[[Realm Of Racket]]'' (No Starch Press, 2013) * ''[[Semantics Engineering with PLT Redex]]'' (MIT Press, 2010) * ''[[How to Design Programs]]'' (MIT Press, 2001) * ''[[A Little Java, A Few Patterns]]'' (MIT Press, 1998) * ''[[The Little MLer]]'' (MIT Press, 1998) * ''[[The Little Schemer]]'' (MIT Press, 4th Ed., 1996) * ''[[The Seasoned Schemer]]'' (MIT Press, 1996)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.ccs.neu.edu/home/matthias/ Matthias at Northeastern University] * [http://www.ccs.neu.edu/ College of Computer and Information Science at Northeastern University]
{{Authority control}}

The '''National Framework of Qualifications''' (NFQ) is a system used to describe levels of educational qualifications in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]. Responsibility for maintaining and developing the framework lies with [[Quality and Qualifications Ireland]] (QQI). Launched in 2003, the NFQ was developed by the [[National Qualifications Authority of Ireland]] as a means of comparing training and qualifications between institutions of education at all levels. It encompasses learning at primary and second level, as well as acting as a benchmark for required standards for graduates of courses offered by QQI, [[Dublin Institute of Technology]] and [[university|universities]].http://www.nfq.ie/nfq/en/learner.html The framework consists of 10 "Levels", ranging from Certificates at Level 1 which signify initial learning to degrees at [[doctoral]] level. A 'fan diagram' [http://www.nfq.ie/nfq/en/images/FanDec2006.jpg] is used to illustrate the progression of the levels.[http://www.nfq.ie/nfq/en/public_resources/presentation.html National Framework of Qualifications - Communication Materials] ==Framework== {| class="wikitable" |- ! [[European Qualifications Framework|EQF]] level ! [[European Higher Education Area|EHEA]] cycle ! NFQ level ! Major award types |- | rowspan="2" | 1 | rowspan="6" |   | 1 | Level 1 Certificate |- | 2 | Level 2 Certificate |- | 2 | 3 | Level 3 Certificate
[[Junior Certificate]] |- | 3 | 4 | Level 4 Certificate
[[Leaving_Certificate_(Ireland)|Leaving Certificate]] |- | 4 | 5 | Level 5 Certificate
Leaving Certificate |- | rowspan="2" | 5 | rowspan="2" | 6 | Advanced Certificate |- | Short cycle within 1st | Higher Certificate |- | 6 | rowspan="2" | 1st | 7 | Ordinary bachelor's degree |- |   | 8 | Honours bachelor's degree
Higher Diploma |- | 7 | 2nd | 9 | Master's Degree
Post-Graduate Diploma |- | 8 | 3rd | 10 | Doctoral Degree
Higher Doctorate |} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.nfq.ie/nfq/en/index.html National Framework of Qualifications website] *[http://www.nqai.ie/interdev_efl.html Relationship] between the [[Common European Framework of Reference for Languages]] and the National Framework of Qualifications {{DEFAULTSORT:National Framework Of Qualifications}} [[Category:Academic transfer]] [[Category:Education in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Educational qualifications in Ireland]]

revision.text:
'''Offline mobile learning''' is the ability to access learning materials on a [[mobile device]] without requiring an [[Internet]] connection.
Generally, [[Web application|web-based applications]] functionalities are dependent on ability to access to the [[Website|Web]]. While there are many practical reasons for an application to access data on a [[Server (computing)|server]], not every feature of an [[Application software|application]] may necessarily need to have such access. [[Online and offline|Offline]] access to such features may enhance the user experience and wider applicability of an application {{Citation needed|date=August 2017}}
''Tasks that require a single service request are well suited to offline scenarios. Such tasks follow a "compose and forward" model, where the user specifies all of the required data for the service request, which is then forwarded to the actual service when the client reconnects. Examples of this type of task are: composing an e-mail, composing a meeting request, and entering order information. All of these tasks are discrete items that the user can complete offline and that result in a single service request.''<ref>MSDN [http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms998439.aspx "Smart Client Offline Application Block"]. Retrieved on 08/01/2010.</ref>
==Mobile Learning: Developing Countries== The developed world’s emphasis on highly sophisticated technological devices is a futuristic dream for most [[Developing country|developing countries]].<ref>{{cite conference|first=K.|last=Masters|title=Low-key m-learning: a realstic introduction of m-learning to developing countries|year=2004|url=http://www.fil.hu/mobil/2005/Masters_final.pdf}}</ref> Nevertheless, these countries realise that [[M-learning|M-Learning]] is more than just using a mobile device for [[Educational technology|E-Learning]], and that it requires an entirely different approach. In order to utilize M-Learning efficiently in these developing countries, there is a need to understand this approach, as technology becomes available.
These mobile technologies have successfully enabled learning opportunities and support to those learners in developing countries who are situated far distances away from [[Educational institution|educational facilities]], and do not have the infrastructure to support access.''
Users in developing countries have the same need for M-Learning to be mobile, accessible and affordable, as those in developed countries do. The very significance of M-Learning is its ability to make learning mobile, away from the [[classroom]] or [[workplace]]. These [[Wireless]] and [[Mobile phone|mobile]] technologies enable learning opportunities to learners who do not have direct access to learning in these places. Many learners in developing countries have trouble accessing the internet, or experience difficulty in affording technology that enables learning in an E-Learning environment. Mobile devices are a cheaper alternative compared to traditional E-Learning equipment such as [[Personal computer|PC]]’s and [[Laptop]]s.''
However, to fully utilize this potential it is imperative to explore the factors that determine mobile telecommunications development in the developing world.<ref>Ping, G. & Adnan, R., 2009. Analysing the Mobile Telecommunications Market in a Developing Country: A Socio-Technical Perspective on Pakistan, Centre for Development Informatics, Instituate for development policy and management, SED.</ref> Delivering mobile services on open hardware and open software not just practically makes sense but can also lower the cost and thus increase the possibility of offering sustainable services in the future.'' While the benefits of open-source software are proven, it is important to conduct a broader study to investigate the potential role of relatively new copyleft approach for custom hardware, as supporting mobile learners in their own socio-cultural contexts of developing countries is a significant challenge.''<ref>Shrestha, S., Moore, J., Abdelnour-Nocera, J. [http://ewh.ieee.org/soc/e/sac/meem/index.php/meem/article/view/134 "Low-cost hardware for ICT4D: what's right and what's left?"]. IIEEE Multidisciplinary Engineering Education Magazine, Vol 6, No 1 (2011).</ref>
==Technologies== A range of devices exist from mobile phones to single-purpose devices such as [[E-book]] readers. Current web technologies provide limited support for offline access to content and therefore web applications are generally designed for online interactions with server and require Internet connection to work. But mobile device is often disconnected by nature and wireless network connection is not available all the time. Device needs to store [[data]] locally in a fully searchable database and application should allow continuous interaction regardless of availability of Internet. Application should also be device and [[Platform as a service|platform]] independent.
==Challenges== Some modern mobile devices have the capability to store thousands of documents and therefore have the potential to be used as powerful offline [[Learning Tools Interoperability|learning tools]].
Typically, the optimal solution is to use the local store as much as possible, since it is usually faster than a remote connection. However, the more work an application does locally, the more code you need to write to implement the feature locally and to synchronize the corresponding data. There is a cost/benefit tradeoff to consider, and some features may not be worthwhile to support locally.<ref>Google [http://code.google.com/apis/gears/architecture.html "Google Gears API Architecture"]. Retrieved on 08/01/2010.</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Education|Technology}} *[[mLearning]] {{-}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.math4mobile.com Math4Mobile - Free offline mobile applications] *[http://www.myfusionmobile.com Fusion Mobile | Nigeria's Mobile m-Learning Platform]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Offline Mobile Learning}} [[Category:Distance education]] [[Category:Mobile technology]]

{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} A '''Philosothon''' is an annual competition wherein students explore philosophical and ethical issues. Philosothons are held in all Australian states, New Zealand, and the UK.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wills|first=Matthew|title=The 2009 Sir Vincent Fairfax Family Foundation Ethics in Leadership Fellowship|url=http://www.churchilltrust.com.au/site_media/fellows/Wills_Matthew_2009.pdf|work=Fellowship Report|publisher=Winston Churchill Trust|accessdate=10 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=UK Philosothon website|url=http://philosothon.co.uk/}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Pritchett|first=Mark|title=The Wellington News|url=http://www.wellington-today.co.uk/article.cfm?id=105096&headline=Philosophers%20debate%20Charlie%20Hebdo%20attack&sectionIs=news&searchyear=2017|accessdate=12 March 2017|newspaper=Wellington Weekly}}</ref>
At a Philosothon school aged students are assessed by university based professional philosophers and score highly where they demonstrate rigour and clarity of thought. An essential component of a Philosothon is the pedagogical model for teaching Philosophy to young people called [[Community of inquiry]]. The event has grown alongside and within the [[Philosophy for Children]] movement. The first Australasian Philosothon was held at Cranbrook School, Sydney in 2011<ref>{{cite news|last=Saunders|first=Alan|title=The Philosophers Zone|url=http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/philosopherszone/philosothon-2011---the-first-australasian-high/2935678|accessdate=10 January 2012|newspaper=ABC}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Rocca|first=Michelle|title=The Victorian Association for Philosophy in Schools|url=http://vaps.vic.edu.au/events/victorian-secondary-philosothon-16th-september-2015|publisher=VAPS|accessdate=11 November 2015}}</ref> and the first UK Philosothon was held in 2012 at King's College, Taunton.<ref>{{cite web|title=Independent Education Today|url=http://ie-today.co.uk/Article/young_philosophers_have_winning_thoughts}}</ref>[[File:Philosothon2007Web2.jpg|thumb|2007 Hale School Philosothon Winning school students with trophy]]
== History == In 2007, [[Hale School]] in Perth Western Australia initiated a project to promote higher order thinking among secondary school students. At the first Philosothon nine local high school teams, each including five students came together for an evening of philosophical investigation. The word 'Philosothon' was created in the first few years of the event by Matthew Wills and Leanne Rucks.<ref>{{cite web|title=Philosothon Website|url=https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Philosothon/|work=History|publisher=Philosothon|accessdate=15 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Philosothon Website|url=http://www.philosothon.org/|work=History|publisher=Philosothon|accessdate=10 January 2012}}</ref>
== Recent history == Following the first Philosothon it was decided to promote the event more broadly to other schools around the country and later in the UK. Philosothons now take place annually in each Australian capital city and in regional locations around the country. They also take place in the UK<ref>{{cite web|title=University of Queenland Philosothon|url=http://www.ctp.uq.edu.au/content/qld-state-philosothon|work=History|publisher=University of Queensland|accessdate=11 November 2015}}</ref> Recently Primary school Philosothons have been conducted in various Art Galleries in some Australian states and in the UK.<ref>{{cite web|last=Worley|first=Peter|title=Philosophy Foundation|url=http://philosophyfoundation.wordpress.com/2014/07/22/uks-first-primary-philosothon/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Etherton|first=Rosemary|title=The National Gallery of Victoria|url=https://www.ngv.vic.gov.au/2014-victorian-primary-school-philosothon/}}</ref>
In 2017 The Templeton Religion Trust awarded $281,656 AUD to the Philosothon project in order to "grow existing Philosothons and support the establishment of new ones, particularly in remote schools and at schools catering for students from low socio-economic backgrounds" in Australasia.<ref>{{cite web|last=W.|first=Justin|title=Daily Nous|url=http://dailynous.com/2017/08/21/large-grant-support-pre-college-philosophy-australasia/}}</ref> [[File:JuniorSchoolPhilosothon.jpg|thumb|A Junior School Philosothon at the Art Gallery of Western Australia]]
== Rationale and process == The rationale for the Philosothon methodology is based on empirical evidence that teaching children reasoning skills early in life greatly improves other cognitive and academic skills and greatly assists learning in general.<ref>{{cite web|last=Prof Stephan Millett|first=Dr Alan Tapper & |title=Educational Philosophy and Theory 'Benefits of Collaborative Philosophical Inquiry in Schools'|year=2011|url=http://legein.perso.sfr.fr/LPP/Benefits%20of%20Collaborative%20Philosophical%20Inquiry%20in%20Schools.pdf | accessdate=10 January 2011}}</ref> Students are given the topic questions in advance and some stimulus reading materials.<ref>{{cite web|title=Philosothon Website|url=http://www.philosothon.org|work=Resources|publisher=Philosothon|accessdate=10 January 2012}}</ref>
Examples of topic questions from recent Philosothons are these:
* Is it moral to fake kindness? ([[Moral Philosophy]]) * Do men and woman have different natures? ([[Metaphysical]]) * Do you have free will? ([[Metaphysical]]) * Should you always listen to the opinions of others? ([[Epistemology]]) * How free should speech be? ([[Political Philosophy]])
Students, teachers and parents gather on a particular evening each year for the event. The students participate in a series of Communities of Inquiry which are facilitated by teachers or Phd. philosophy students from the local universities. While participating in this process students are scored by Philosophy lecturers also from local universities. The scores are then collated, ranked and later in the evening awards are given to students at each age level and encouragement awards to the most promising male and female philosopher. Also a trophy is awarded to the winning school.<ref>{{cite web|last=Flood|first=Gary & |title= A Marathon for the Mind|year=2014|url=https://www.pdcnet.org/pdc/bvdb.nsf/purchase?openform&fp=tpm&id=tpm_2014_0067_0010_0015| accessdate=10 November 2014}}</ref>
== Criticisms and responses == Some might argue that Philosophy cannot be undertaken in the context of a competition.<ref>{{cite website|last=TALIAFERRO|first=CHARLES |title=Ask a Philosopher|website=Ask a Philosopher?|year=2010|volume=12|issue=1|url=http://www.askphilosophers.org/question/3267|accessdate=5 May 2017}}</ref> They believe that by ranking individuals the process of developing a Community of Philosophical Inquiry is fundamentally compromised. However, others have responded that many students forget they are involved in a competition and engage in the exact sort of investigation and collaboration we would hope to see in Philosophy. Others have suggested that the same process is undertaken in any academic institution, tertiary or secondary where students are ranked against criteria. The only difference is that one of the more important criteria in a COI is collaboration.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wills|first=Matthew|title=Philosothon|journal=American Philosophical Association|year=2012|volume=12|issue=1|url=http://c.ymcdn.com/sites/www.apaonline.org/resource/collection/808CBF9D-D8E6-44A7-AE13-41A70645A525/v12n1_Teaching.pdf|accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref> [[File:NationalPhilosothonWinners.jpg|thumb|Winners of the 2011 Australasian Philosothon Christ Church Grammar School]]
== Australasian Philosothon == In July 2011 the Federation of Australasian Philosophy in Schools Associations (FAPSA) decided to host the first National Philosothon at [[Cranbrook School, Sydney|Cranbrook School]]. Each Australian state sent three teams (those schools that won the 2010 Philosothon in each state) and so twelve schools in total arrived in Sydney to participate in the inaugural event.<ref>{{cite web|title=Australian Association of Philosophy|url=http://aap.org.au/event-319903|accessdate=10 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Dr Poulton|first=Janette|title= -Victorian Association for Philosophy in Schools|url=http://vaps.vic.edu.au/events/victorian-secondary-philosothon-16th-september-2015|work=Victorian Philosothon|publisher=VAPS|accessdate=10 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=FAPSA|url=http://fapsa.org.au/philosothon/|work=Federal Association for Philosophy in Schools|publisher=FAPSA|accessdate=10 January 2012}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|title=Philosophy Now UK Journal|url=http://philosophynow.org/issues/104/News_September_October_2014|work=National Philosothon|publisher=Philosophy Now|accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref> The 2012 it was held at Bond University and AB Paterson College on the Gold Coast. In 2013 it was held in Melbourne, Victoria and hosted by the National Art Gallery of Victoria and Ballarat Grammar's City campus. In 2014 Hale School in Perth Western Australia hosted the event.<ref>{{cite web|title=FAPSA|url=http://philosothon.org/2014AustralasianPhilosothon/philosothonstudents.mp3|work=ABC Drive Radio|publisher=ABC|accessdate=10 July 2014}}</ref> and in 2015 North Sydney Girls High School hosted the 5th Annual FAPSA Australasian Philosothon. In 2016 Churchie in Brisbane hosted it and in 2017 St Andrew's Cathedral College in Sydney hosted the event.
== Other countries == Philosothons have been run in the UK since 2013. Revd. Mark Smith & [[Julie Arliss]] from the Philosophy of Religion and Ethics Department at [[King's College, Taunton]], UK, have spearheaded the Philosothon movement in the United Kingdom in collaboration with Dr Michael Lacewing from [[Heythrop College]] and Lizzy Lewis from [[Sapere]].<ref>http://www.kings-taunton.co.uk/philosothon/</ref> Wells Cathedral College won the first event. Since then Philosothons have been run annually around the UK including many Primary School Philosothons hosted by the Philosophy Foundation. Other Philosothons have been held around the UK.<ref>{{cite news|last=Davies|first=Sian|title=The Southern Daily Echo|url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/news/11155830.display/|accessdate=12 March 2017|newspaper=Wellington Weekly}}</ref>
== Primary and Middle School Philosothons == In 2012 an inaugural Primary School Philosothon was held at the [[National Gallery of Victoria]] (NGV).<ref>{{cite web|last=Worley|first=Peter|title=Philosophy Foundation|url=http://philosophyfoundation.wordpress.com/2014/07/22/uks-first-primary-philosothon/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Etherton|first=Rosemary|title=The National Gallery of Victoria|url=https://www.ngv.vic.gov.au/2014-victorian-primary-school-philosothon/}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|last=Dr D'Olympio|first=Laura|title=The Conversation|url=http://theconversation.com/philosophy-in-schools-promoting-critical-creative-and-caring-thinking-44578}}</ref> In 2013 the first WA Primary school Philosothon was hosted by John XXIII College at the Art Gallery of WA. Since then Annual Primary School Philosothons have been conducted in Victoria, WA and the UK.<ref>{{cite web|title=Philosophy Foundation Website|url=https://philosophyfoundation.wordpress.com/2014/07/22/uks-first-primary-philosothon/}}</ref>
== Results == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Australasian Philosothons !! First !! Second !! Third !! page.title: R v Headteacher and Governors of Denbigh High School, ex p Begum

revision.comment: adding case citations for the HC and EWCA decisions
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=December 2016}} {{original research|date=December 2016}} {{primary sources|date=December 2016}} }} {{Infobox court case | name = R (Begum) v Denbigh High School | image = Jilbab in Zanzibar (cropped).jpg | caption = [[Jilbāb]], of which its wearing is the center of this case. | court = [[House of Lords]] | date decided = 2006 | citations = [2006] [http://www.bailii.org/uk/cases/UKHL/2006/15.html UKHL 15], [2007] 1 AC 100 | judges = [[Tom Bingham, Baron Bingham of Cornhill|Lord Bingham of Cornhill]], [[Lord Scott of Foscote]], [[Lord Hoffmann]], [[Lord Nicholls|Lord Nicholls of Birkenhead]], [[Brenda Hale, Baroness Hale of Richmond|Baroness Hale of Richmond]] | keywords = Religious dress, religious discrimination, [[Human Rights Act 1998]] }}
'''''R (Begum) v Governors of Denbigh High School''''' [2006] is a [[House of Lords]] case on the legal regulation of religious symbols and dress under the [[Human Rights Act 1998]].<ref>[http://www.bailii.org/uk/cases/UKHL/2006/15.html UKHL 15, House of Lords Decisions] Retrieved 2014-06-25</ref>
The case involved Shabina Begum, a Muslim pupil at [[Denbigh High School, Luton|Denbigh High School]] in [[Luton]], UK, who sued her school.<ref name="Emon2012">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wFbWEPGx7SkC&pg=PA291|title=Religious Pluralism and Islamic Law: Dhimmis and Others in the Empire of Law|author=Anver M. Emon|date=26 July 2012|publisher=OUP Oxford|isbn=978-0-19-966163-3|page=291}}</ref> Begum opposed the schools requirement that she wear the [[shalwar kameez]] Denbigh school uniform instead of a longer, looser Muslim gown (a [[jilbāb]]), on the grounds that the uniform was not compliant with [[Sharia]] law. Begum lost her case in the High Court,<ref>[2004] EWHC 1389 (Admin)</ref> won on appeal to the Court of Appeal,<ref>[2005] EWCA Civ 199</ref> but then lost in March 2006 when the Judicial Committee of the House of Lords unanimously overturned the first appeal.<ref name="bbc-22-3-06">{{cite news|title=School wins Muslim dress appeal|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/education/4832072.stm|accessdate=20 February 2016|agency=BBC News|date=22 March 2006}}</ref><ref name="Langlaude2007">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uVmwCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA227|title=The Right of the Child to Religious Freedom in International Law|author=Sylvie Langlaude|date=12 December 2007|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-474-2350-8|page=227}}</ref>
==The case== Shabina Begum ({{lang-bn|শবিনা বেগম}}; born in the UK, aged 16 at the time and of [[British Bangladeshi|Bangladeshi]] origin), was a pupil at [[Denbigh High School, Luton|Denbigh High School]] in [[Luton]], [[Bedfordshire]]. Four out of the six parent governors were Muslims, the Chair of the Luton Council of Mosques was a community governor and three of the LEA governors were also Muslims. However the school also contained a significant number of pupils of other faiths and the school wished to be inclusive in serving the needs of this diverse community and regarded the school uniform as promoting a sense of communal identity. In addition to uniforms incorporating trousers or skirts, female pupils are also offered a uniform based on the [[Pakistan]]i or [[Punjab region|Punjabi]] [[shalwar kameez]] with optional [[khimar]]. The school uniform was decided upon in consultation with local mosques, religious organisations and parents. The School considered the shalwar kameez ideal as it was worn by several faith groups and, accordingly, helped to minimise the differences between them.
For two years, Ms. Begum attended the school without complaint, wearing the shalwar kameez, but in September 2002, Ms. Begum, accompanied by her brother and another young male, went to the school and asked that she be allowed to wear the long coat-like garment known as the [[jilbāb]]. In the opinion of Begum and her supporters, the particular form of shalwar kameez offered by the school was relatively close-fitting with short sleeves, and was therefore not compliant with the requirements of [[Sartorial hijab|Islamic dress]] as they are stated in [[Sharia]] law. Shabina refused to attend for three years unless she was allowed to wear the jilbab to school. She said she believed that this was required by her [[Muslim]] faith, but also in contravention of the [[school uniform]] policy. In addition, the jilbab was, in the opinion of Begum and her supporters, a more culturally-neutral form of Islamic attire.
The school's supporters claimed that after Begum's parents had died, she had come under the undue influence of her brother Shuweb Rahman. They also argued that if Begum was allowed to attend classes wearing jilbab, other pupils would feel under pressure to adopt stricter forms of Islamic dress.{{fact?|date=December 2016}}
Begum, with her brother, issued a claim for judicial review of the school's decision not to allow her to wear the jilbab at school. The claim was made on the grounds that the school had interfered with her right to manifest her religion (Article 9 of the [[European Convention on Human Rights]]) and her right to education (Article 2(1) of the first protocol).
==Judgment==
===Appeals=== Begum lost the case in the [[EWHC|High Court]], but later won on appeal to the [[EWCA|Court of Appeal]]. The school [[appeal]]ed against this decision, and the case was heard by the [[Judicial functions of the House of Lords|Judicial Committee of the House of Lords]]. The [[Department for Education and Skills (United Kingdom)|Department for Education and Skills]] was allowed to make submissions in the hearing in the House of Lords. The House of Lords ruled in favour of the school. Begum was represented in the Court of Appeal and the House of Lords by the former Prime Minister's wife [[Cherie Blair|Cherie Blair QC]].
===House of Lords=== [[Tom Bingham, Baron Bingham of Cornhill|Lord Bingham of Cornhill]] stressed at the outset of his judgment that,
{{Cquote|this case concerns a particular pupil and a particular school in a particular place at a particular time. It must be resolved on facts which are now, for purposes of the appeal, agreed. The House is not, and could not be, invited to rule on whether Islamic dress, or any feature of Islamic dress, should or should not be permitted in the schools of this country.}}
The Law Lords took the view that a person's right to hold a particular religious belief was absolute (i.e. could not be interfered with), but that a person's right to manifest a particular religious belief was qualified (i.e. it could be interfered with if there was a justification).
Three of the five Law Lords held that Begum's rights had not been interfered with<ref>{{Halsbury|88A|School uniform, curriculum and discipline.|444|6}}</ref> (Lord Bingham, [[Lord Scott of Foscote]] and [[Lord Hoffmann]]), and two held that they had ([[Lord Nicholls|Lord Nicholls of Birkenhead]] and [[Brenda Hale, Baroness Hale of Richmond|Baroness Hale of Richmond]]).
All five agreed, however, that in this particular case there were justifiable grounds for interference, one of the grounds being to protect the rights of other female students at the school who would not wish to be pressured into adopting a more extreme form of dress.
==See also== {{Clist belief}} * [[Islam in the United Kingdom]] * [[Islamic dress in Europe]] * [[French law on secularity and conspicuous religious symbols in schools]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9hN-vAb4dQg Video of Shabina Begum Just before verdict] * [https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200506/ldjudgmt/jd060322/begum-1.htm Judgment of the House of Lords] * [http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWCA/Civ/2005/199.html The Appeal Court judgment] (March 2, 2005) * [http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Admin/2004/1389.html The High Court judgment] (June 15, 2004) * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/4832072.stm School wins Muslim dress appeal] (March 22, 2006) * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/3808073.stm Schoolgirl loses Muslim gown case] (June 15, 2004) * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/beds/bucks/herts/4310545.stm Schoolgirl wins Muslim gown case] (March 2, 2005)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Begum, Shabina}} [[Category:Civil rights case law]] [[Category:Religion in England]] [[Category:Islamic dress controversy in Europe]] [[Category:2006 in case law]] [[Category:2006 in British law]] [[Category:House of Lords cases]] [[Category:Religion and children]] [[Category:Religion and education]] [[Category:Education case law]] [[Category:2006 in education]] [[Category:2006 in religion]] [[Category:Education in England]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Website | name = Smart.fm | favicon = | screenshot = Smart-fm.png | screenshot_size = 210px | url = http://www.smart.fm/ | commercial = Yes | type = Social Learning, Language Learning, General Learning | key_people = Paul Greenberg, <small>[[CEO]]</small>; [[Andrew Smith Lewis]], <small>[[Chairman]]</small> | registration = Free | language = Includes [[Japanese language|Japanese]], [[Korean language|Korean]], [[English language|English]] | author = Cerego Japan, Inc. | current status = Closed }}
'''Smart.fm''' (formerly ''iKnow!'') was a social learning- and [[community website]] created by [[Cerego|Cerego Japan, Inc.]] The website used [[Spaced repetition|spaced repetition algorithms]] (SRS) to assist users in committing facts to long term memory and increasing learning speed. Users could create, manage and share lists of facts to memorize; as well as learn a number of languages.<ref name="smartfm-venturebeat-1">{{cite web | url=https://venturebeat.com/2009/09/07/is-smartfms-facebook-app-may-be-smarter-than-you-think/ | title=Smart.fm’s Facebook app may be smarter than you think | accessdate=2009-09-27 | author = Anthony Ha | date = 2009-09-07 | work = Digital.VentureBeat.com }} </ref> Progress could be monitored with tests.<ref>http://www.crunchbase.com/product/iknow-2, accessed 3/25/2009</ref> The data was used to automatically plan a curriculum and learning strategy for the users.<ref name="techcrunch-iknow">{{cite web | url=https://techcrunch.com/2008/10/15/iknow-is-a-social-learning-platform-that-can-really-make-you-smarter-opens-api/ | title=iKnow Is A Social Learning Platform That Can Really Make You Smarter. Opens API. | accessdate=2009-09-22 | author = Serkan Toto | date = 2008-10-15 | work = TechCrunch.com }} </ref><ref name="cerego-funding">{{cite web | url=https://techcrunch.com/2008/10/15/iknow-is-a-social-learning-platform-that-can-really-make-you-smarter-opens-api/ | title=Cerego Raises $3.4 Million For Smart.fm, Launches Facebook Friend Quiz | accessdate=2009-09-22 | author = Leena Rao | date = 2009-09-10 | work = TechCrunch.com }} </ref> In addition to the website base, Smart.fm also had a Facebook application.
== History == Smart.fm was created by Japan-based company [[Cerego|Cerego Japan, Inc.]], initially featuring language-learning and [[product brand|branded]] under the name iKnow! (iKnow.co.jp). The original platform focused on English learners in [[Japan]] and attracted roughly 300,000 users in its first year.<ref name="crunchbase-cerego">{{cite web | url=http://www.crunchbase.com/company/cerego-japan-inc | title=Cerego Japan Inc. | accessdate=2009-09-27 | author = | date = 2009-09-17 | work = CrunchBase }} </ref> On November 24, 2008 the platform turned to world-wide audience when it added another 188 languages. The upgrade also included tools for users to create learning content; sample sentences and timed tests. Cerego had raised US$20 million in funding at the time and was staffed by 22 employees.<ref name="smartfm-venturebeat-1" /><ref name="venturebeat-iknow">{{cite web | url=https://venturebeat.com/2008/11/24/cerego-releases-iknow-social-language-learning-platform/ | title=Cerego releases iKnow! social language learning platform | accessdate=2009-09-27 | author = Dean Takahashi | date = 2008-11-24 | work = Digital.VentureBeat.com }} </ref>
The site's name was changed to Smart.fm on March 5, 2009 when the [[software platform|platform]] introduced an upgrade which enabled users to add learning content of any kind. The re-branding was sudden, and users complained about the new [[graphical user interface|interface]] and new name.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} About the new name, Cerego's ''Russell Moench'' explained in an official announcement: "''we see ourselves more like your personal learning station than an online classroom or teacher or textbook''."<ref name="smartfm-announcement">{{cite web | url=http://smart.fm/blog/en/2009/3/4/139782-hi-there-we-re-smart-fm | title=Hi there. We're smart.fm | accessdate=2009-03-19 | author = Russell Moench | date = 2009-03-04 | work = Smart.fm weblog }} </ref>
== Technology == Cerego's Smart.fm used [[spaced repetition]] techniques to assist users in organizing learning content, increase learning speed and improve recollection. The system was based on established methods of learning derived from [[cognitive science|cognitive]]- and [[neuroscience]] research; continuously analyzing performance, on a long- and short-term basis, making dynamic adjustments to learning exercises. The data was used to automatically plan a [[curriculum]] and learning strategy for the users.<ref name="techcrunch-iknow" /><ref name="cerego-funding" />
== Closure == On January 27, 2011, [[Cerego|Cerego Japan, Inc.]] announced the planned closure of the Smart.fm free service for March 31, 2011. The Smart.fm service has since been replaced with Cerego's paid subscription-based language learning site, iKnow!<ref name="smartfm-closure">{{cite web | url=http://blog.smart.fm/en/2011/01/27/closing-the-smart-fm-service/ | title=Closing the Smart.fm Service | accessdate=2011-01-27 | author = Smart.fm | date = 2011-01-27 | work = Smart.fm }} </ref>
== References == {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Spaced repetition software]]

[[Image:Behavior Intervention by using Images.jpg|thumb|SBCC by health practitioner]] [[File:Development-Entertainment Continuum.png|thumb|SBCC on the Development-Entertainment spectrum.]] '''Social and behavior change communication''' ('''SBCC'''), often also only "'''BCC'''" or "'''Communication for Development''' ('''C4D''')" is an interactive process of any intervention with [[individuals]], [[communities]] and/or societies (as integrated with an overall program) to develop [[communication]] strategies to promote positive behaviors which are appropriate to their settings and there by solve world's most pressing health problems. This in turn provides a supportive environment which will enable people to initiate, sustain and maintain positive and desirable [[behavior]] outcomes.<ref name="UNFPA">{{Cite journal | title = COMMUNICATION/BEHAVIOR CHANGE TOOLS | journal = Entertainment-Education | volume = 1 | pages = 1–6 | publisher = United Nations Population Funds | url = http://www.sbccimplementationkits.org/demandrmnch//wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Programme-Brief-Entertainment-Education.pdf | date = January 2002}}</ref>
SBCC is the strategic use of communication to promote positive health outcomes, based on proven theories and models of [[Behavior change (public health)|behavior change]]. SBCC employs a systematic process beginning with formative research and behavior analysis, followed by communication planning, implementation, and monitoring and evaluation. Audiences are carefully segmented, messages and materials are pre-tested, and mass media (which include radio, television, billboards, print material, internet), interpersonal channels (such as client-provider interaction, group presentations) and community mobilisation are used to achieve defined behavioral objectives.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.measureevaluation.org/prh/rh_indicators/crosscutting/bcc|title=Behavior Change Communication — MEASURE Evaluation|website=www.measureevaluation.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-23}}</ref>
BCC should not be confused with [[behavior modification]], a term with specific meaning in a [[clinical psychiatry]] setting.
== Background == Providing people with information and teaching them how they should behave does not lead to desirable change in their response/behavior. However, when there is a supportive environment with information and communication (teaching) then there is a desirable change in the behavior of the target group. Thus, SBCC is proved to be an instructional intervention which has a close interface with education and communication. It is a strategic and group oriented form of communication to perceive a desired change in behavior of target group.<ref>{{Cite web |title=A Tool Box for Building Health Communication Capacity |url=http://www.globalhealthcommunication.org/tools/29 |accessdate=29 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100204073405/http://www.globalhealthcommunication.org/tools/29 |archivedate=4 February 2010 |df= }}</ref>
However, it is not as easy as it sounds, as there is no one-size-fits all strategy for any intervention. Interventions are context specific. Therefore, there is a need for proper information management and sharing. It is advised to document and report the interventions that worked somewhere, for example, the kind of messages, the medium and the audience.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Davidson|displayauthors=etal|first=|date=|year=2003|title=Evidence-based behaviour change medicine: what is it and how do we achieve it?|url=|journal=Annals of Behavioral Medicine|volume=26|pages=161–171|via=}}</ref>
==Steps== SBCC is the comprehensive process in which one passes through the stages:
Unaware > Aware > Concerned > Knowledgeable > Motivated to change > Practicing trial behavior change > Sustained behavior change[[Image:Behavior Change Communication.jpg|thumb|SBCC in classroom practices]]
It involves the following steps:<ref name=":0" /> # State program goals # Involve stakeholders # Identify target populations # Conduct formative BCC assessments # Segment target populations # Define behavior change objectives # Define SBCC strategy & monitoring and evaluation plan # Develop communication products # Pretest # Implement and monitor # Evaluate # Analyze feedback and revise
== Enabling factors == Behavior change is influenced by motivation from others (external influence) as well as from within oneself (internal influence). Internal influence plays a significant role in creating more enjoyment of a behavior change, instilling a sense of ownership of the new behavior, which in turn instills a sense of ownership of the changed behavior.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Osbaldiston|first=R|last2=Sheldon|first2=K|year=2002|editor-last=Schmuck|editor-first=A|editor2-last=Schultz|editor2-first=W|title=Social dilemmas and sustainable development: Promoting the motivation to cooperate with the future.|url=|journal=Psychology of Sustainability|publisher=Boston: Kluwer|volume=|pages=37–57|via=}}</ref> When designing SBCC strategies, enabling factors that affect the outcome must be considered. The following are some of the factors:<ref name=":0" /> * Effective communication * Enabling environment, which include policies, human rights community values and norms * User-friendly, accessible services and commodities
==Theories== SBCC has several levels at which it can be implemented. Each level includes several theories. Each level (and each theory) employs specific communication channels.
;Individual level * Health belief theory * Theory of reasoned action and planned behavior * Stages of change * Social learning
;Community level * Diffusion of innovations theory * Community mobilization
;Change in organizations * 4 stage change
;Public policy Level * Distinct stages of initiation, action, implementation, evaluation and re-formulation
[[File:SBCC Summit in Bali 2018.jpg|thumb|The SBCC Summit 2018 in Bali, Indonesia, focusing on social and behavior change communication and featuring [[Entertainment-Education]].]] [[File:SBCC Summit 2018 Crowd in Nusa Dua, Indonesia.jpg|thumb|Over 1,200 attendees came to the 2018 SBCC Summit, where Entertainment-Education was a main topic among Social and Behavior Chance Communications professionals.]]
==Strategies== SBCC is different from the ordinary instructional method of communication and is target specific. A society consists of many sub-groups. The strategy for SBCC will vary from group to group. The following points are important while considering the SBCC strategy.<ref name="BCC_AIDS">{{Cite journal | last = Aggleton | first = P. | author-link = | title = Behavior change communication strategies | journal = AIDS Educ Prev. | volume = 9 | issue = 2 | pages = 111–23 | date = April 1997 | pmid = 9167797 }}</ref> * Vulnerability/risk factor of the target group * The vulnerability/risk factor of the group which is to be addressed * The conflict and obstacles in the way to desired change in behavior * Type of message and communication media which can best be used to reach the target group * Type of resources available and assessment of existing knowledge of the target group about the issue which is going to be dealt with
There can be several more points in this list. A successful SBCC requires lots of research and meticulous planning about the knowledge content of the subject and behavior/attitude pattern of the target group.<ref name="UNFPA" />
[[Social marketing]] has been described as a tool for [[sustainable behaviour]] change.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Merritt|first1=Rowena|last2=Truss|first2=Aiden|last3=Hopwood|first3=Toby|title=Social marketing can help achieve sustainable behaviour change|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/blog/social-marketing-behaviour-change|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=11 June 2017|date=17 March 2011}}</ref>
==Implications== SBCC has proven effective in several health areas, such as increasing the use of family planning methods,reducing the spread of malaria and other infectious diseases, and improving newborn and maternal health.
SBCC is an effective tool for dealing with many community and group related problems. BCC has been adapted as an effective strategy for [[community mobilization]], health and environment education and various public outreach programs.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Woods N. | first = Lisa | authorlink = | title = BEHAVIOUR CHANGE COMMUNICATION IN EMERGENCIES: A TOOLKIT | publisher = United Nations Children’s Fund | location = Nepal | year = 2006 | page = 246 | url = http://www.unicef.org/ceecis/BCC_full_pdf.pdf | isbn = 99946-896-1-4}}</ref> Enhanced knowledge about the behavior change process has facilitated the design of communications programs to reduce the risk of HIV transmission and AIDS. A wide variety of health promotion strategies use communication as either an educational or norm-forming strategy. In addition, specific strategies must be designed for high-risk groups such as women, young people, injecting drug abusers, homosexuals and HIV positive groups.<ref name="BCC_AIDS" />
==Role in HIV/AIDS== SBCC constitutes of effective communication which is central to the success of interventions to reduce the risk of HIV infection. It plays a role to:<ref name="BCC_AIDS" /><ref name=":0">{{cite document|title=Behavior Change Communication (BCC) for HIV/AIDS: a strategic framework|date=September 2002 |publisher=Family Health International (FHI)|url=http://www.hivpolicy.org/Library/HPP000533.pdf}}</ref>
* Increase knowledge * Stimulate community dialogue * Promote essential attitude change * Advocate for policy changes * Create a demand for information and services * Reduce stigma and discrimination * Promote services for prevention and care
== See also == * [[Attitude change]] * [[Behavior change (public health)]] * [[Entertainment-Education]] * [[Design for behaviour change]] * [[Johns Hopkins University Center for Communication Programs]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20180405153401/http://www.epragati.in/download/Final-5.0.pdf/ Community Mobilization and Participation] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150210182051/http://www.globalhealthcommunication.org/tools/strategy/behavior_change_communication Behavior Change Communication Tools & Publications]: FHI * Development Communication – a research article by Kumar, Rajesh: https://web.archive.org/web/20130927085358/https://caluniv.ac.in/Global%20mdia%20journal/Winter%20Issue%20December%20%202011%20Articles/AR-3%20Kumar.pdf * [http://www.comminit.com/global/category/sites/global The Communication Initiative] – a central knowledge base for experts in the field * [https://c4d.org/ C4D Network] – a localized, country-specific network for practitioners
[[Category:Behavioural sciences]] [[Category:Community]] [[Category:Community organizing]] [[Category:Attitude change]] [[Category:Communication]]
