revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = The Educated Mind | image = The Educated Mind Cover Pic.jpeg | image_size = 200px | author = Kieran Egan | release_date = 1997 | isbn = 0-226-19036-6 }} '''''The Educated Mind: How Cognitive Tools Shape Our Understanding''''' is a 1997 book on [[Philosophy of education|educational theory]] by [[Kieran Egan (educationist)|Kieran Egan]].
== Main arguments ==
=== Criticism of previous education theories === Egan argues that much of educational theorizing pivots around three basic ideas of what the aim of education should be:
# to educate people in content that would give them a "privileged and rational view of reality"<ref>Kieran Egan (1997). The educated mind (page 13). Chicago: University of Chicago Press. {{ISBN|0-226-19036-6}}.</ref> ([[Plato]]). Here we find the following ideas: reason and knowledge can provide a privileged access to the world; knowledge drives the student mind development; education is an [[epistemological]] process. # to realize the right of every individual to pursue his own educational curriculum through self-discovery ([[Jean-Jacques Rousseau|Rousseau]]). Here we also find the ideas that student development drives knowledge and that education is a psychological process. # to '''Socialize the child''' - to homogenize children and ensure that they can fulfill a useful role in society, according to its values and beliefs.
Egan argues in Chapter One that "these three ideas are mutually incompatible, and this is the primary cause of our long-continuing educational crisis";<ref name="EdMindIntro">{{cite book|author=[[Kieran Egan (educationist)|Kieran Egan]] |title=The educated mind (introduction)|location=Chicago | publisher=University of Chicago Press |year=1997 |isbn=0-226-19036-6|url=http://www.educ.sfu.ca/kegan/EdMindIntro.html}}</ref> the present educational program in much of the West attempts to integrate all three of these incompatible ideas, resulting in a failure to effectively achieve any of the three.<ref name="MacNeil_review">D. James MacNeil, review of ''The educated mind'', for the 21st Century Learning Initiative, September 1998</ref>
=== How knowledge grows in the mind === Egan's proposed solution to the education problem which he identifies is to show how knowledge and understanding develop in the mind as we pick up sets of cognitive tools in our negotiations with those around us and with the natural world itself. This individual process, he argues, mirrors, as a result of logical and psychological pressures, a related process in human cultural development. Thus, he describes his theory as a "cultural recapitulation" theory, taking care to differentiate it from the conceptions of recapitulation common in the late 19th century and early 20th century. According to Egan, individuals can pick up sets of cognitive tools that will coalesce into five distinctive kinds of understanding: # '''Somatic''' - (before [[language acquisition]]) the physical abilities of one's own body are discovered, as are our emotions; somatic understanding includes the communicating activity that precedes the development of language; as the child grows and learns language, this kind of understanding survives in the way children "model their overall social structure in play". # '''Mythic''' - binary opposites (e.g. Tall/Short or Good/Evil), images, metaphor, and story-structure are prominent tools in pre-literate sense-making. # '''Romantic''' - the limits of reality are discovered and rational thinking begins, connected with the development of literacy. Egan connects this stage with the desire to explore the limits of reality, an interest in the transcendent qualities of things, and "engagement with knowledge represented as a product of human emotions and intentions" (p. 254) # '''Philosophic''' - the discovery of principles which underlie patterns and limits found in data; ordering knowledge into coherent general schemes. # '''Ironic''' - it involves the "mental flexibility to recognize how inadequately flexible are our minds, and the languages we use, to the world we try to represent in them"; it therefore includes the ability to consider alternative philosophic explanations, and is characterized by a Socratic stance in the world.
"Drawing from an extensive study of [[cultural history]] and [[evolutionary history]] and the field of cognitive psychology and anthropology, Egan gives a detailed account of how these various forms of understanding have been created and distinguished in our cultural history".<ref name="Polito2005">Theodora Polito, ''[http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/bpl/epat/2005/00000037/00000004/art00003 Educational Theory as Theory of Culture: A Vichian perspective on the educational theories of John Dewey and Kieran Egan]'' Educational Philosophy and Theory, Vol. 37, No. 4, 2005</ref>
Each stage includes a set of "cognitive tools", as Egan calls them, that enrich our understanding of reality. Egan suggests that recapitulating these stages is an alternative to the contradictions between the Platonic, Rousseauian and socialising goals of education.
Egan resists the suggestion that religious understanding could be a further last stage, arguing instead that religious explanations are examples of ironic understanding preserving a richly developed somatic understanding.
== Connections with other authors == Egan's main influence comes from the Russian psychologist [[Lev Vygotsky]].<ref name="MacNeil_review" /> The idea of applying [[theory of recapitulation]] to education came from 19th century philosopher [[Herbert Spencer]], although Egan uses it in a very different way. Egan also uses educational ideas from [[William Wordsworth]] and expresses regret that Wordworth's ideas, because they were expressed in poetry, are rarely considered today.
==In popular culture== The same year the essay was published (1997), Italian comedian-satirist [[Daniele Luttazzi]] used Egan's ideas for his character ''Prof. Fontecedro'' in the popular TV show ''Mai dire gol'', aired on [[Italia 1]]. Fontecedro was satirizing the inadequacies of the Italian [[school|school system]], and the reforms proposed by [[Luigi Berlinguer]], 1996-2000 Ministry of Education of Italy. Fontecedro's sketches brought Egan's theory to extreme levels with surreal humor. The [[joke]]s were later published in the book ''Cosmico!'' (1998, [[Mondadori]], {{ISBN|88-04-46479-8}}), where the five stages of mind development are also cited at pp. 45–47.
==See also== *[[Merlin Donald]] *[[Northrop Frye]]'s ''[[The Educated Imagination]]'' (1964)
== References == <references/>
previous works on ironic knowledge: *Bogel, Fredric V. "Irony, Inference, and Critical Understanding." Yale Review 69 (1980): 503-19.
==Editions== *{{cite book|author=[[Kieran Egan (educationist)|Kieran Egan]] |title=The educated mind: How Cognitive Tools Shape Our Understanding|location=Chicago | publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]] |year=1997 |isbn=0-226-19036-6}}
==External links== *[http://www.educ.sfu.ca/kegan/EdMind.html Book dedicated section] in Egan official website *''[https://www.sfu.ca/~egan/ConceptionsDev.html Conceptions of Development in Education]'', Egan's essay that explain the main ideas of the book *From the Imaginative Education Research Group: [http://www.ierg.net/about/briefguide.html A brief guide to imaginative education], [http://www.ierg.net/about/cog_thoughts.html Some thoughts on "Cognitive tools"], [http://www.ierg.net/about/cog_myth.html Cognitive tools that come along with oral language], [http://www.ierg.net/about/cog_lit.html Cognitive tools that come along with literacy], [http://www.ierg.net/about/cog_theory.html Cognitive tools that come along with theoretic thinking] *[https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0226190390 Excerpts] from google books *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071009175718/http://www.kentupper.com/resources/Entheogens+$26+Education--JDEA+2003.pdf Using entheogens as cognitive tools to foster Somatic and Mythic types of understanding]
'''Reviews''' *[http://reader2.com/forestfortrees/author:Egan,Kieran reader2.com]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Educated Mind, The}} [[Category:1997 books]] [[Category:Education books]] [[Category:Philosophy books]] [[Category:Books about irony]] [[Category:Pedagogy]] [[Category:Stage theories]]

revision.text:
{{About|the two-body problem of dual-career academic couples|the two-body problem in classical mechanics|two-body problem}}
The '''two-body problem''' is a [[dilemma]] for life partners (for e.g. spouses or any other couple) in [[academia]], relating to the difficulty of both spouses obtaining jobs at the same university or within a reasonable commuting distance from each other. The central dilemma is thus a [[no-win situation]] in which if the couple wishes to stay together one of them may be forced to abandon an academic career, or if both wish to pursue academic careers the relationship may falter due to the spouses being constantly separated.<ref name="Benton2009">Benton, Thomas H. (pen name of [[William Pannapacker]]) (2009). "[http://chronicle.com/article/Just-Dont-Go-Part-2/44786/ Just Don't Go, Part 2]". ''The Chronicle of Higher Education'', 13 March 2009, accessed 21 June 2012.</ref> Compromises the couple makes while trying to negotiate the two-body problem have implications for gender inequality.<ref name="Wong2017">{{cite journal |last1=Wong|first1=Jaclyn|date=16 March 2017 |title=Competing Desires: How Young Adult Couples Negotiate Moving for Career Opportunities|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/0891243217695520|journal=Gender & Society|volume=31|issue=2|pages=171–196|doi= 10.1177/0891243217695520 |access-date=16 April 2017}}</ref> The term ''two-body problem'' has been used in the context of working couples since at least the mid-1990s.<ref name="Benton2009"/><ref name="McNeil & Sher">{{cite web|last=McNeil|first=Laurie|title=REPORT ON THE DUAL-CAREER-COUPLE SURVEY|url=http://www.physics.wm.edu/~sher/survey.html}}</ref> It alludes to the insolvable [[three-body problem]] in classical mechanics.
More than 70 percent of academic faculty have a working partner, while more than a third of faculty have an academic partner.<ref name=clayman>{{cite web|author1=Londa Schiebinger |author2=Andrea Davies Henderson |author3=Shannon K. Gilmartin |title=Dual-Career Academic Couples: What Universities Need to Know|url=https://gender.stanford.edu/publications/dual-career-academic-couples-what-universities-need-know|accessdate=19 March 2012|publisher=The Clayman Institute for Gender Research}}</ref>
==Solutions== {{unreferenced-section|date=June 2017}} Typical solutions include: * two [[tenure-track]] positions at the same university * two tenure-track positions at two nearby universities (daily commutes possible) * two tenure-track positions with one or both partners commuting between two geographically separate institutions (daily commutes impossible because of distance; partners may be separated weekly or for semesters at a time, depending on their circumstances) * one tenure-track position shared (if they are in the same field) * one tenure-track position and one instructor position * one tenure-track position and one industry position * one tenure-track position and one administration position at a same university * one tenure-track position and one position in government or with a private consulting firm (feasible in fields such as [[engineering]] and [[management]], probably infeasible in [[humanities]])
Although it is not an ideal solution, a possible outcome is a break-up of the relationship. Long distance commuting certainly places a strain on relationships, especially when maintained over long periods (years or even decades). Many academic institutes recognize the two-body problem is a challenging issue when they hire a new faculty member, and prepare policies to help dual-career academic couples to settle down at their institutions. An institution in a small, rural state such as [[Wyoming]] may be under increased pressure to hire a spouse than in a large metropolitan area with many colleges and universities such as [[Boston]].
More proactive institutions may establish funds and procedures to assist with this situation. Frequently a university will seek to hire one person in a couple, thereby making the other the "trailing spouse." One approach is for a tenure-track position to be funded for the trailing spouse be a combination of funds from both academic departments involved with additional funds from the dean and/or provost. Substantial resources must be offered external to the department that would accept the trailing spouse, as this department would not typically be in the position to hire said person nor would that particular person necessarily rank highly if a search were to be conducted. For this reason, it is not unusual for departments to reject the trailing spouse even if substantial external funds are made available. This makes the problem particularly intractable, as qualified persons may remain unemployed simply because they are not an ideal fit for the trailing department. More commonly, institutions do not have such proactive programs in place.
==See also== * [[Academia]] * [[Academic mobility]] * [[Higher education]] * [[Opportunity trap]] *[[Dual-career commuter couples]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.historians.org/jobs-and-professional-development/statements-standards-and-guidelines-of-the-discipline/best-practices-on-spousal/partner-hiring Spousal Hiring Policies] by the [[American Historical Association]]
[[Category:Academia]] [[Category:Higher education]] [[Category:Education economics]] [[Category:Academic culture]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox university | name = West Virginia University | image_name = West Virginia University seal.svg | image_upright = 0.8 | motto = Πίστει τὴν ἀρετήν, ἐν δὲ τῇ ἀρετῇ τὴν γνῶσιν ([[Greek language|Greek]]) | mottoeng = To faith virtue, and to virtue knowledge. ([[Second Epistle of Peter|2 Peter]] 1:5) | established = 1867 | type = {{•}}[[Public university|Public]]
{{•}}[[Flagship university|Flagship]]
{{•}}[[Land-grant university|Land-grant]]
{{•}}[[Space grant college|Space-grant]]
{{•}}[[Satellite campus|Multi-campus]] | endowment = $566.42 million (2017)As of June 30, 2017. {{cite web |url=http://www.nacubo.org/Documents/research/2017-Endowment-Market-Values-2.pdf |title=U.S. and Canadian Institutions Listed by Fiscal Year (FY) 2017 Endowment Market Value and Change in Endowment Market Value from FY2016 to FY2017 |accessdate=January 30, 2018 |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20180306015434/http://www.nacubo.org/Documents/research/2017-Endowment-Market-Values-2.pdf |archive-date=March 6, 2018 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} | academic_affiliation = [[Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities|APLU]]
[[Oak Ridge Associated Universities|ORAU]]
[[Southeastern Universities Research Association|SURA]] | staff = 7,566 | faculty = 1,870 | president = [[E. Gordon Gee]] | provost = Joyce McConnell{{cite news|title=WVU's Wheatly stepping down; Gee names McConnell to provost position July 1 |url=http://wvutoday.wvu.edu/n/2014/06/17/wvu-s-wheatly-stepping-down-gee-names-mcconnell-to-provost-position-july-1 |accessdate=July 1, 2004|work=WVU Today|publisher=West Virginia University |date=June 17, 2014}} | students = 29,175 (Fall 2014){{Cite web|title=About WVU|url=http://about.wvu.edu/wvu-facts|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=July 26, 2015}} | undergrad = 22,563 (Fall 2014) | postgrad = 5,001 (Fall 2014) | doctoral = 1,611 (Fall 2014) | city = [[Morgantown, West Virginia|Morgantown]] | state = [[West Virginia]] | country = U.S. | coor = {{Coord|39.63582|N|79.95453|W|source:placeopedia|display = inline,title|format = dms}} | campus = WVU Downtown
{{convert|913|acre|km2|1}} | colors = Old Gold and Blue{{cite web|title=WVU Brand Center|url=http://brand.wvu.edu/downloads-toolkit/color-palette |accessdate=June 7, 2016}}
{{college color boxes|West Virginia Mountaineers}} | mascot = [[West Virginia Mountaineer|The Mountaineer]] | nickname = [[West Virginia Mountaineers|Mountaineers]] | sporting_affiliations = [[NCAA Division I]] – [[Big 12 Conference|Big 12]]
[[American Collegiate Hockey Association|ACHA Division 1]] ([[College Hockey Mid-America|CHMA]]) | website = {{url|www.wvu.edu}} | logo = West Virginia University logo.svg | logo_size = 250 }} '''West Virginia University''' ('''WVU''') is a [[public university|public]], [[Land-grant university|land-grant]], [[Space-grant university|space-grant]], [[Research university|research]]-intensive university in [[Morgantown, West Virginia]], United States. Its other campuses include the [[West Virginia University Institute of Technology]] in [[Beckley, West Virginia|Beckley]] and [[Potomac State College of West Virginia University]] in [[Keyser, West Virginia|Keyser]]; and a second clinical campus for the University's medical and dental schools at [[Charleston Area Medical Center]] in [[Charleston, West Virginia|Charleston]]. WVU Extension Service provides outreach with offices in all of West Virginia's 55 counties. Since 2001, WVU has been governed by the West Virginia University [[Board of Governors]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wvu.edu/~bog/powers.htm|title=WVU.edu: Board of Governors – "Powers & Duties"|accessdate=October 17, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070601230815/http://www.wvu.edu/~bog/powers.htm|archivedate=June 1, 2007|df=}} Enrollment for the Fall 2015 semester was 28,776 for the main campus, while enrollment across all campuses was 32,348.{{cite web |url=http://wvutoday.wvu.edu/n/2013/10/23/wvu-s-entering-class-has-higher-academic-credentials-student-body-more-diverse|title=WVU's Entering Class Has Higher Academic Credentials, Student Body More Diverse|publisher=West Virginia University The University|accessdate=March 5, 2014}} WVU offers 191 bachelor's, master's, doctoral, and professional degree programs in 15 colleges.{{Cite web|title=About WVU|url=http://about.wvu.edu/wvu-facts|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=November 27, 2014}} WVU has produced 24 [[Rhodes Scholarship|Rhodes Scholars]], including former WVU president [[David C. Hardesty, Jr.]] The University has also produced 36 [[Barry M. Goldwater Scholarship|Goldwater Scholars]], 22 [[Truman Scholar]]s, and five members of ''[[USA Today]]''{{'s}} "All‑USA College Academic First Team." ==History== {{main|History of West Virginia University}} [[File:WVU Cadet Corps.jpg|thumb|left|250px|WVU's Cadet Corps, c. 1880, from the site of where Oglebay Hall is today, Martin Hall (center) and Woodburn Hall (right) are in the background.]] ===Founding the university=== Under the terms of the 1862 [[Morrill Land-Grant Colleges Act]], the West Virginia Legislature created the '''Agricultural College of West Virginia''' on February 7, 1867, and the school officially opened on September 2 of the same year.{{cite book|last=Doherty|first=William T.|author2=Festus P. Summers|title=West Virginia University: Symbol of Unity in a Sectionalized State |publisher=[[West Virginia University Press]]|year=1982|page=8|isbn=0-937058-16-5}}{{cite news|title= West Virginia College|newspaper= Morgantown Weekly Post |date=August 10, 1867|url=http://www.wvculture.org/history/education/wvu01.html|accessdate=August 16, 2010}} On December 4, 1868, lawmakers renamed the college West Virginia University to represent a broader range of higher education.{{cite book|last=Doherty|first=William T.|author2=Festus P. Summers|title=West Virginia University: Symbol of Unity in a Sectionalized State |publisher=[[West Virginia University Press]]|year=1982|page=11|isbn=0-937058-16-5}} It built on the grounds of three former academies, the Monongalia Academy of 1814, the Morgantown Female Academy of 1831, and Woodburn Female Seminary of 1858.{{cite web |url=http://monongalia.ext.wvu.edu/about_monongalia_county |title=About Monongalia County |publisher=WVU Extension Services |accessdate=August 17, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110202090003/http://monongalia.ext.wvu.edu/about_monongalia_county |archivedate=February 2, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} Upon its founding, the local newspaper claimed that "a place more eligible for the quiet and successful pursuit of science and literature is nowhere to be found". The first campus building was constructed in 1870 as University Hall, and was renamed Martin Hall in 1889 in honor of West Virginia University's first president, the Rev. Alexander Martin of [[Scotland]].{{cite web|url=http://journalism.wvu.edu/about_us/about_martin_hall|title=A Brief History of Marin Hall|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=August 17, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100831152605/http://journalism.wvu.edu/about_us/about_martin_hall|archivedate=August 31, 2010|df=}} After a fire destroyed the Woodburn Seminary building in 1873, the centerpiece of what is now Woodburn Hall was completed in 1876, under the name New Hall. The name was changed to University Building in 1878, when the College of Law was founded as the first professional school in the state of West Virginia.{{cite web|url=http://law.wvu.edu/about_us/deans_message/history|title=WVU College of Law History|publisher=WVU College of Law|accessdate=August 18, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820015539/http://law.wvu.edu/about_us/deans_message/history|archivedate=August 20, 2010|df=}} The precursor to [[Woodburn Circle]] was finished in 1893 when Chitwood Hall (then Science Hall) was constructed on the bluff's north side. In 1909 a north wing was added to University Building, and the facility was renamed Woodburn Hall. Throughout the next decade, Woodburn Hall underwent several renovations and additions, including the construction of the south wing and east tower (in 1930) housing the [[Seth Thomas (clockmaker)|Seth Thomas]] clock.{{cite web|url=http://www.ia.wvu.edu/~magazine/issues/fall2001/htmlfiles/woodburn.html|title=Woodburn Hall, WVU's Historic Centerpiece|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=August 17, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719062631/http://www.ia.wvu.edu/~magazine/issues/fall2001/htmlfiles/woodburn.html|archivedate=July 19, 2011|df=}} The three Woodburn Circle buildings were listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1974.{{NRISref|version=2010a}}{{cite web |url=http://www.wvculture.org/shpo/nr/pdf/monongalia/74002014.pdf|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory Nomination Form: Woodburn Circle|date=February 1974|accessdate=August 18, 2011|author1=George A. Smyth|author2=Ted McGee|author3=James E. Harding|last-author-amp=yes|publisher=State of West Virginia, West Virginia Division of Culture and History, Historic Preservation}} In 1899, the [[Vance Farmhouse|Vance Farm]] was acquired for the West Virginia University Experiment Station.{{cite web |url=http://www.wvculture.org/shpo/nr/pdf/monongalia/91001731.pdf|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory Nomination Form: Vance Farmhouse|date=January 1991|accessdate=August 18, 2011|author=Lee R. Maddex|publisher=State of West Virginia, West Virginia Division of Culture and History, Historic Preservation}} WVU was required to have a Cadet Corps under the terms of the [[Morrill Land-Grant Acts|Morrill Act of 1862]], which allowed for the creation of [[land-grant college]]s. The [[United States Department of War]]—a predecessor of the [[U.S. Department of Defense]]—offered military equipment to the university at no charge, forming the basis of the school's Military Tactics department. The heavy military influence led to opposition of female enrollment that lasted through the first decade of the university.{{cite web|url=http://wvuhistory.wvu.edu/historyofwvu|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071127130337/http://wvuhistory.wvu.edu/historyofwvu|dead-url=yes|archive-date=November 27, 2007|title=West Virginia University: 1867–2003|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=August 17, 2010}} The trend changed in 1889, when ten women were allowed to enroll and seek degrees at the university. In June 1891, Harriet Lyon became the first woman to receive a degree from West Virginia University, finishing first in the class ahead of all male students. Lyon's academic success supported the acceptance of women in the university as students and educators.{{cite book|author=WVU Student Government|title=Dream Big, Dream Here|publisher=Tapestry Press|year=2007|chapter=8|isbn=1-59830-150-0}} [[File:WV football team 1891.jpg|thumb|350px|right|West Virginia University's first football team, formed in 1891]] During the University's early years, daily chapel services and roll call for all students were mandatory, limiting time for student recreation. Following the removal of these obligations, students became active in extracurricular activities and established many of the school's first athletic and student organizations. The first edition of the student newspaper known as the ''Athenaeum'', now ''The Daily Athenaeum'', was published in 1887, and the ''[[West Virginia Law Review]]'' became the fourth-oldest law review in the United States when it was founded in 1894. [[Phi Kappa Psi]] was the first [[Fraternities and sororities in North America|fraternity]] on campus, founded May 23, 1890, while Kappa Delta, the first [[Fraternities and sororities in North America|sorority]] at WVU, was established in 1899. The first [[American football|football]] team was formed in 1891, and the first basketball team appeared in 1903.{{cite web|url=http://sportsintegration.wvu.edu/index.html|title=A History of the Integration of Sports at WVU|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=August 17, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100831010953/http://sportsintegration.wvu.edu/index.html|archivedate=August 31, 2010|df=}} ===Early 20th century=== [[File:Boyd Arnold Mascot.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Boyd "Slim" Arnold, the first Mountaineer mascot to don the traditional buckskin uniform. His selection in 1937 marked the beginning of an official process to name the mascot annually.]] The University's outlook at the turn of the 20th century was optimistic, as the school constructed the first library in present-day [[Stewart Hall (Morgantown, West Virginia)|Stewart Hall]] in 1902.{{cite web|url=http://www.wvculture.org/shpo/nr/pdf/monongalia/80004034.pdf|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory Nomination Form: Stewart Hall|date=March 1980 |accessdate=August 18, 2011|author=Rodney S. Collins|publisher=State of West Virginia, West Virginia Division of Culture and History, Historic Preservation}} The campus welcomed U.S. President [[William Howard Taft]] to campus for WVU President Thomas Hodges's inauguration in 1911. On November 2, 1911, President Taft delivered the address "World Wide Speech", from the front porch of [[Purinton House]].{{cite web |url=http://www.wvculture.org/shpo/nr/pdf/monongalia/85003206.pdf|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory Nomination Form: Purinton House|date=July 1985|accessdate=August 18, 2011 |author=Randall Gooden|publisher=State of West Virginia, West Virginia Division of Culture and History, Historic Preservation}} However, the University's efforts to attract more qualified educators, increase enrollment, and expand the campus was hindered during a period that saw two [[World war|World Wars]] and the [[Great Depression]]. With a heavy military influence in the University, many students left college to join the army during [[World War I]], and the local [[ROTC]] was organized in 1916.{{cite web|url=http://www.ia.wvu.edu/~magazine/issues/winter2000/html%20files/yearbyyear.html|title=WVU Year-by-Year|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=August 19, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100627064613/http://www.ia.wvu.edu/~magazine/issues/winter2000/html%20files/yearbyyear.html|archivedate=June 27, 2010|df=}} Women's involvement in the war efforts at home led to the creation of Women's Hall dormitory, now [[Stalnaker Hall]], in 1918.{{cite web |url=http://www.wvculture.org/shpo/nr/pdf/monongalia/85003205.pdf|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory Nomination Form: Stalnaker Hall|date=July 1985|accessdate=August 18, 2011 |author=Randall Gooden|publisher=State of West Virginia, West Virginia Division of Culture and History, Historic Preservation}} Despite its wartime struggles, the University established the disciplines of [[biology]], [[medicine]], [[journalism]], [[pharmacy]], and the first [[mining engineering|mining]] program in the nation. In 1918, [[Oglebay Hall]] was built to house the expanded [[agriculture]] and [[forestry]] programs. Additionally, the first dedicated sports facilities were constructed including "The Ark" for basketball in 1918, and the original [[Mountaineer Field (1924)|Mountaineer Field]] in 1925. Stansbury Hall was built in 1928 and included a new basketball arena named [[WVU Fieldhouse|"The Fieldhouse"]] that held 6,000 spectators.{{cite book|author=Bill Bradley|title=ESPN College Basketball Encyclopedia: The Complete History of the Men's Game|publisher=ESPN|year=2009|page=36|isbn=0-345-51392-4}} [[Elizabeth Moore Hall]], the woman's physical education building, was also completed in 1928.{{cite web|url=http://www.wvculture.org/shpo/nr/pdf/monongalia/85003208.pdf|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory Nomination Form: Elizabeth Moore Hall|date=July 1985 |accessdate=August 18, 2011|author=Randall Gooden|publisher=State of West Virginia, West Virginia Division of Culture and History, Historic Preservation}} [[Men's Hall]], the first dormitory built for men on campus, was built in 1935, and was funded in part by the [[Works Progress Administration]].{{cite web |url=http://www.wvculture.org/shpo/nr/pdf/monongalia/89002309.pdf |title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory Nomination Form: Men's Hall|date=January 1989|accessdate=August 18, 2011 |author1=Stanley Bumgardner|author2=Barbara J. Howe |lastauthoramp=yes|publisher=State of West Virginia, West Virginia Division of Culture and History, Historic Preservation}} The Mountaineer mascot was adopted during the late 1920s, with an unofficial process to select the Mountaineer through 1936. An official selection process began naming the mascot annually in 1937, with Boyd "Slim" Arnold becoming the first Mountaineer to wear the [[Buckskins|buckskin]] uniform.{{cite web|url=http://msnsportsnet.com/page.cfm?section=9614|title=The Mountaineer|publisher=MSN Sports|accessdate=August 19, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714130110/http://msnsportsnet.com/page.cfm?section=9614|archivedate=July 14, 2011|df=mdy-all}} As male students left for [[World War II]] in 1939, women became more prominent in the University and surpassed the number of males on campus for the first time in 1943. Soldiers returning from the war qualified for the [[G.I. Bill]] and helped increase enrollment to over 8,000 students for the first time, but the University's facilities were becoming inadequate to accommodate the surging student population. ===A campus divided=== [[File:WVU Evansdale Campus.jpg|thumb|right|250px|A view of the Evansdale campus and many new facilities constructed around 1970, including the iconic [[WVU Coliseum]]]] Preparation for the [[baby boomer]] generation and plans for curriculum expansion led to the purchase of land for the Evansdale and Medical campuses. The growth of downtown Morgantown limited the space available on the original campus; therefore, the new site was nearly two miles north on what had been farmland. Beginning in the late 1950s the University experienced the most rapid period of growth in its history. In 1957, WVU opened a Medical Center on the new campus and founded the first school of dentistry in West Virginia. The basketball program reached a new level of success when the University admitted future 14‑time [[List of NBA All-Stars|NBA All-Star]] and [[Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame]] player [[Jerry West]], who led the team to the national championship game in 1959.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/history/players/west_bio.html|title=NBA Encyclopedia Playoff Edition |publisher=ESPN|accessdate=August 20, 2010}} As enrollment approached 14,000 in the 1960s, the University continued expansion plans by building the Evansdale Residential Complex to house approximately 1,800 students, the Mountainlair student union, and several engineering and creative arts facilities on the Evansdale campus. In 1970 the [[WVU Coliseum]], a basketball facility with a capacity of 14,000, opened near the new campus. As the facilities expanded, the University researched ways to move its growing student population across the split campuses and to solve its worsening traffic congestion. The resulting [[Morgantown Personal Rapid Transit|Personal Rapid Transit]] system opened in 1973 as the world's first automated rapid transit system.{{cite web|url=http://www.progressiveengineer.com/PEWebBackissues2002/PEWeb%2024%20Mar%2002-2/PRT.htm|title=Still in a Class of Its Own|publisher=Progressive Engineer|accessdate=August 20, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60lRBniz0?url=http://www.progressiveengineer.com/PEWebBackissues2002/PEWeb%2024%20Mar%2002-2/PRT.htm|archivedate=August 7, 2011|df=}} ===A new era=== [[File:Woodburn hall wvu.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Woodburn Hall is one of the oldest buildings at West Virginia University and has long been a symbol of the university.]] The student population continued to grow in the late 1970s, reaching 22,000. With no room for growth on the downtown campus, the [[Mountaineer Field (1924)|football stadium]] was closed, and the new [[Mountaineer Field]] was opened near the Medical campus on September 6, 1980. Mountaineer Field would later be named Mountaineer Field at Milan Puskar Stadium. After an $8 million donation to the University, Ruby Memorial Hospital opened on the Medical campus in 1988, providing the state's first level-one trauma center. Early the next year, the undefeated Mountaineer football team, led by [[Major Harris]], made it to the national championship game before losing to [[University of Notre Dame|Notre Dame]] in the [[1989 Fiesta Bowl|Fiesta Bowl]]. During the 1990s the University developed several recreational activities for students, including FallFest and WVU "Up All Night". While the programs were created to provide safe entertainment for students and to combat WVU's inclusion as the nation's top [[party school]]s,{{cite web|url=http://www.brandonsun.com/world/breaking-news/list-of-top-party-schools-by-princeton-review-99770794.html?thx+y|title=List of Party Schools By Princeton Review|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=August 13, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} they also garnered national attention as solutions for reducing alcohol consumption and partying on college campuses across the country.{{cite web |url=http://www.allbusiness.com/education-training/students-student-life/14364607-1.html|title=WVU officials say program worth the cost|publisher=Charleston Daily Mail|accessdate=August 12, 2010}}[http://www.ia.wvu.edu/~magazine/fall98/alcohol.html Party Response] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928222613/http://www.ia.wvu.edu/~magazine/fall98/alcohol.html |date=September 28, 2011 }} In 2001 a 34 million-dollar, {{convert|177000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} recreation facility opened on the Evansdale campus, providing students with exercise facilities, recreational activities, and personal training programs.{{cite web|url=http://www.facilityplanners.com/ht/a/GetDocumentAction/i/3949|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710215649/http://www.facilityplanners.com/ht/a/GetDocumentAction/i/3949|dead-url=yes|archive-date=July 10, 2011|title=Amazing New Rec Center|publisher=Charleston Gazette|accessdate=August 13, 2010}} WVU reached a new level of athletic success to start the new millennium. The football team featured a 3‑0 [[BCS bowl]] record, ten consecutive bowl game appearances, a #1 ranking in the [[USA Today Coaches Poll|''USA Today'' Coaches' Poll]], three consecutive 11‑win seasons amassing a 33–5 record, 41 consecutive weeks in the top 25, and 6 conference championships.{{cite web|url=http://www.msnsportsnet.com/page.cfm?sport=football&show=65|title=A Championship Program|publisher=MSN Sports Net|accessdate=August 20, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/rankings/_/year/2007/week/14|title=2007 NCAA Football Rankings – Week 14 (November 25)|publisher=ESPN/AP |accessdate=August 20, 2010}} The men's basketball team won the [[2007 National Invitation Tournament|2007 NIT Championship]] and the [[2010 Big East Men's Basketball Tournament|2010 Big East championship]], while appearing four times in the sweet sixteen, twice in the elite-eight, and once in the final-four of the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA tournament]].{{cite web|url=http://www.msnsportsnet.com/page.cfm?sport=mbball&show=25|title=2007 NIT Champions|publisher=NIT|accessdate=August 20, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nit.org/sports/m-nit/recaps/032907aaa.html|title=Tradition of Champions|publisher=MSN Sports Net|accessdate=August 20, 2010 |deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090322115106/http://www.nit.org/sports/m-nit/recaps/032907aaa.html|archivedate=March 22, 2009 }} The athletic successes brought the University a new level of national exposure, and enrollment has since increased to nearly 30,000 students.{{cite web|url=http://wvutoday.wvu.edu/n/2009/8/26/7986|title=WVU set record fall enrollment|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=August 20, 2010}} On April 24, 2008, the ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'' reported the university had improperly granted an [[MBA]] degree to [[Heather Bresch]], the daughter of the state's governor [[Joe Manchin]] and an employee of [[Mylan]], a pharmaceutical company whose then-chairman Milan Puskar was one of the University's largest donors.Ian Urbina, [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/22/us/22heather.html?_r=1 "University Investigates Whether Governor's Daughter Earned Degree"], ''New York Times'', January 22, 2008 In the aftermath, the University determined Bresch's degree had been awarded without having the prerequisite requirements met and rescinded it, leading to the resignation of president [[Michael Garrison (politician)|Michael Garrison]], provost Gerald Lang, and business school dean Steve Sears. Garrison had been profiled as a trend toward non-traditional university presidents by the ''[[Chronicle of Higher Education]]''{{cite news|last=Fain|first=Paul|title=The Lobbyist as President|url=http://chronicle.com/article/The-Lobbyist-as-President/10502|accessdate=September 20, 2012|newspaper=Chronicle of Higher Education|date=February 15, 2008}} and ''[[Inside Higher Ed]]'',{{cite news|last=Redden|first=Elizabeth|title=The Nontraditional President |url=http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2008/03/14/nontraditional|accessdate=September 20, 2012|newspaper=Inside Higher Ed|date=March 14, 2008}} but the Faculty Senate approved a vote of no confidence in the search that selected him.[http://www.da.wvu.edu/show_article.php?&story_id=28841 ''Daily Athenaeum'' (May 23, 2007): "Faculty Senate votes 'no confidence'", by Tricia Fulks] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071111223755/http://www.da.wvu.edu/show_article.php?&story_id=28841 |date=November 11, 2007 }} C. Peter McGrath was named interim president in August 2008.{{cite web|url=http://president.wvu.edu/|title=WVU Admin|accessdate=October 17, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131215121108/http://president.wvu.edu/|archivedate=December 15, 2013|df=mdy-all}} [[James P. Clements]] became WVU's 23rd president on June 30, 2009. He had previously served as provost at [[Towson University]].[http://wvgazette.com/ap/ApTopStories/200906300058 "WVU's 23rd president officially takes reins"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324091644/http://wvgazette.com/ap/ApTopStories/200906300058 |date=March 24, 2012 }} On September 16, 2009, Michele G. Wheatly was named Provost and Vice President for Academic Affairs.{{cite web|url=http://wvutoday.wvu.edu/n/2009/09/16/wheatly-named-provost-at-wvu|title=Wheatly named Provost at WVU|work=WVUToday|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} On November 11, 2013 James P. Clements was selected to be Clemson University's 15th president.{{cite web|url=http://wvutoday.wvu.edu/n/2013/11/11/james-p-clements-named-president-of-clemson-university|title=James P. Clements named president of Clemson University|work=WVUToday|accessdate=November 27, 2014}} On December 10, 2013 it was announced that [[Gordon Gee|E. Gordon Gee]] would serve as interim president effective January 6, 2014. This is Dr. Gee's second time in this role having first served as president of WVU in 1981.{{cite web |url=http://wvutoday.wvu.edu/n/2013/12/10/welcome-back-gee-wvu-community-greets-returning-president-with-open-arms|title=Welcome back, Gee: WVU community greets returning president with open arms|work=WVUToday|accessdate=November 27, 2014}} ==Academics== {{Infobox US university ranking | USNWR_NU=170 | Wamo_NU=120{{cite web |title=2014 National Universities Rankings |date=n.d. |accessdate=May 25, 2015 |website=Washington Monthly |url=http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/college_guide/rankings-2014/national-universities-rank-all.php |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140828025627/http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/college_guide/rankings-2014/national-universities-rank-all.php |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 28, 2014 |df= }} | Forbes=360 }} WVU is designated as an "R1" Research University (Very High Research Activity) by the [[Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching]].{{cite web |url=http://carnegieclassifications.iu.edu/lookup/srp.php?clq=%7B%22basic2005_ids%22%3A%2215%22%7D|title=Carnegie Classifications: Standard Listings |accessdate=June 6, 2016}} Funding from external sources for total sponsored programs is $174 million. WVU is affiliated with the Rockefeller Neurosciences Institute, dedicated to the study of Alzheimer's and other diseases that affect the brain.{{cite web|url=http://www.brni.org/ |title=Blanchette Rockefeller Neurosciences Institute – Home |author=Blanchette Rockefeller Neurosciences Institute|date=June 7, 2015}} WVU is also a leader in biometric technology research and the Federal Bureau of Investigation's lead academic partner in biometrics research.{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703376504575491704156387646?mod=WSJ_article_RecentColumns_PathtoProfession|title=Wall Street Journal Employer Rankings By Major |newspaper=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=September 17, 2010| date=September 14, 2010}}{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703369704575462023026245534?mod=WSJ_article_RecentColumns_PathtoProfession|title=Wall Street Journal Employer Rankings: The Next Twenty|publisher=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=September 17, 2010| date=September 13, 2010}} ===Colleges and schools=== [[File:Wvu-woodburn-hall.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Woodburn Hall was completed in 1876 and is the centerpiece of Woodburn Circle, the oldest part of the WVU campus.]] [[File:woodburn-circle-aerial.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Woodburn Circle on the downtown campus – Martin Hall (top), Woodburn Hall (right), Chitwood Hall (bottom)]] [[File:StalnakerHallWVU2008.jpg|thumb|300px|Stalnaker Hall is the oldest residence hall on campus.{{cite web |url=http://stalnaker.housing.wvu.edu/ |title=Stalnaker Hall |publisher=West Virginia University |accessdate=February 6, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5eNaoAnsl?url=http://stalnaker.housing.wvu.edu/ |archivedate=February 6, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}]] West Virginia University is organized into 15 degree-granting colleges or schools and also offers an Honors College. *Davis College of Agriculture, Natural Resources & Design *Eberly College of Arts & Sciences *[[College of Business and Economics (WVU)|College of Business & Economics]] *College of Creative Arts *Benjamin M. Statler College of Engineering & Mineral Resources *College of Education & Human Services *[[West Virginia University Reed College of Media|Reed College of Media]] *[[West Virginia University College of Law|College of Law]] *[[West Virginia University School of Dentistry|School of Dentistry]] *[[West Virginia University School of Medicine|School of Medicine]] *School of Nursing *School of Pharmacy *[[West Virginia University School of Public Health|School of Public Health]] *College of Physical Activity & Sport Sciences *University College *University of Interspecies Communication *Honors College The Eberly College of Arts & Sciences was officially established in 1895. It is home to many academic disciplines including: social and behavioral sciences, literature and the humanities, as well as mathematics and natural resources. It is the largest and most diverse college at WVU. ===Divisional campuses=== WVU has two divisional campuses: *[[Potomac State College of West Virginia University]] in Keyser *[[West Virginia University Institute of Technology]] in Beckley [[West Virginia University at Parkersburg]], a primarily 2-year school, was a regional campus of WVU but has been independent since 2009.{{cite web|title=FAQs about WVU Relationship|url=http://www.wvup.edu/about/about-wvu-parkersburg/faqs-about-wvu-relationship/|publisher=[[West Virginia University at Parkersburg]]|accessdate=April 2, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150410194808/http://www.wvup.edu/about/about-wvu-parkersburg/faqs-about-wvu-relationship/|archivedate=April 10, 2015|df=}} ===Areas of study=== [[Forensics]] and Investigative Science is a nationally recognized program at WVU, originally created through a partnership with the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]. The program is accredited by the [[American Academy of Forensic Sciences]] and is the official library holdings repository for the [[International Association for Identification]]. The program includes three main areas of emphasis, including the examiner track, which specializes in crime scene investigation and comparison sciences, the biology track, which specializes in body fluids and DNA analysis, and the chemistry track, when specializes in the chemical identification of seized drugs, fire debris, trace evidence and explosives. Facilities include four "crime-scene" houses, a vehicle processing garage, a ballistics laboratory and numerous traditional laboratories and classrooms in Ming Hsieh Hall and Oglebay Hall. A separate Criminology & Investigative Sciences major was later added to the Eberly College of Arts and Sciences. The College of Business and Economics also provides a certificate in forensic accounting and fraud examination. [[File:rubyHSC.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Health Sciences Campus]] WVU robotics teams have won several international competitions such as the NASA Robotic Mining Competition and the NASA/NIA RASC-AL Exploration Robot-OPS Challenge. In 2016, a WVU team{{Cite web|url=http://www2.statler.wvu.edu/~irl/page34.html|title=NASA_Challenge|website=www2.statler.wvu.edu|access-date=September 29, 2016}} led by Dr. Yu Gu won the final NASA Sample Return Robot Centennial Challenge with a $750,000 prize.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/directorates/spacetech/centennial_challenges/feature/2016_sample_return_robot_challenge_award.html|title=NASA Awards $750K in Sample Return Robot Challenge|last=Hall|first=Loura|date=September 8, 2016|access-date=September 29, 2016}} [[File:WVU_SRR14.jpg|thumb|302x302px|The WVU Robotics Team that won NASA Centennial Challenge (NASA/Joel Kowsky)]] [[Biometrics]] is an engineering-centric field of study offered at WVU, the first institution in the world to establish a [[bachelor of science]] degree in Biometric Systems. In 2003 the University also founded the initial chapter of the Student Society for the Advancement of Biometrics (SSAB).{{cite web|url=http://www.csee.wvu.edu/ssab/|title=SSAB WVU Chapter|accessdate=October 17, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208214520/http://www.csee.wvu.edu/ssab/|archive-date=December 8, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The program, in the Lane Department of Computer Science and Electrical Engineering (LCSEE), provides a firm understanding of the underlying [[electrical engineering]] and [[computer engineering]] disciplines that support [[biometric]] applications. On February 6, 2008, WVU became the national academic leader for the [[FBI]]'s biometric research.{{cite web |url=https://www.fbi.gov/news/pressrel/press-releases/west-virginia-university-named-national-leader-for-fbi-biometrics-research|title=FBI Press|work=FBI|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} WVU is also the founding site for the Center for Identification Technology Research (CITeR), focusing on biometrics and [[Digital identity|identification technology]]. CITeR maintains and develops collaborative relationships with other academic institutions to meet research needs.{{cite web|url=http://www.citer.wvu.edu/|title=CITeR|accessdate=October 17, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141017042137/http://www.citer.wvu.edu/|archive-date=October 17, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The Robert C. Byrd Health Sciences Center is on West Virginia University's Evansdale Campus and houses the Schools of Dentistry, Medicine, Nursing, and Pharmacy. These schools grant doctoral and professional degrees in 16 different fields, as well as a variety of other [[Master's degree|Master's]] and [[Bachelor's degree|Bachelor's]] degrees.{{cite web |url=http://www.wvu.edu/majors/index.html|title=Majors Listed by College & School|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=November 24, 2008}} For 2012 ''[[U.S. News and World Report]]'' ranked WVU's Medical School ninth in the United States for [[Rural health|rural medicine]].[http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/grad/med/rural usnews.com: Medical Specialty Rankings: Rural medicine] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218115200/http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/grad/med/rural |date=December 18, 2008 }} Also on the Health Sciences Campus is WVU's local teaching hospital, [https://web.archive.org/web/20120712003306/http://wvuhealthcare.com/wvuh/Hospitals-Clinics/Ruby-Memorial-Hospital/Ruby-Memorial-Hospital Ruby Memorial Hospital], which is one of only two designated Trauma I hospitals in the state and has also been designated a magnet hospital for its ability to attract and retain high quality nursing staff. ==Campus== [[File:MountainlairWVU2008.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The [[Mountainlair]] Student Union is a popular place for students on campus.]] The Morgantown campus comprises three sub-campuses. The original main campus, typically called the Downtown Campus, is in the Monongahela River valley on the fringes of Morgantown. This part of campus includes eight academic buildings on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. The Downtown Campus comprises several architectural styles predominantly featuring red brick including Victorian Second Empire, Federal, Neoclassical, and Collegiate Gothic among others. The Evansdale Campus, a mile and a half north-northwest, on a rise above the flood plain of the [[Monongahela River]], was developed in the 1950s and 1960s to accommodate a growing student population, since space for expansion was limited at the Downtown Campus. The Health Sciences Campus, in the same outlying area (but on the other side of a ridge), includes the Robert C. Byrd Health Sciences Center, the Erma Byrd Biomedical Research Facility, Ruby Memorial Hospital, Chestnut Ridge Hospital, Mary Babb Randolph Cancer Center, WVU Healthcare Physicians Office Center, Blanchette Rockefeller Neurosciences Institute, WVU Eye Institute, and the WVU Children's Hospital. The Health Sciences Campus is near [[Mountaineer Field at Milan Puskar Stadium|Mountaineer Field]], over a ridge from the Evansdale Campus. ===Transportation=== {{See also|Morgantown Personal Rapid Transit}} [[File:Morgantown PRT - Beechurst Station.jpg|thumb|left|300px|The PRT shuttles students to and from WVU's Health Sciences, Evansdale, and Downtown Campuses.]] Due to the distance between WVU's three campuses, the university built the innovative Personal Rapid Transit (PRT) system to link the campuses (Downtown, Evansdale, and Health Sciences) and reduce student traffic on local highways. [[Boeing]] began construction on the Personal Rapid Transit (PRT) system in 1972. The unique aspect that makes the system "personal" is that a rider specifies their destination when entering the system and, depending on system load, the PRT can dispatch a car that will travel directly to that station. WVU students, faculty and staff ride for free; they swipe their magnetically encoded ID cards through the turnstiles when entering the stations. Others pay a cash fare of $0.50. The PRT began operation in 1973, with U.S. President [[Richard Nixon]]'s daughter, Tricia, aboard one of five prototype cars for a demonstration ride.{{cite web|url=http://wvutoday.wvu.edu/news/page/4104/|title=WVU News and Information Services (July 13, 2004 press release): "WVU PRT Station to Bear Name of People-Mover's Creator"|work=WVUToday|accessdate=October 17, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071111224014/http://wvutoday.wvu.edu/news/page/4104/|archive-date=November 11, 2007|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The PRT handles 16,000 riders per day ({{as of|2005|lc=y}}) and uses approximately 70 cars. The system has {{convert|8.7|mi}} of guideway track and five stations: Walnut, Beechurst, Engineering, Towers, and Medical/Health Sciences. The vehicles are rubber-tired, but the cars have constant contact with a separate electrified rail. [[Steam]] heating keeps the elevated guideway free of snow and ice. Although most students use the PRT, this technology has not been replicated at other sites for various reasons, including the high cost of maintaining the heated track system in winter.{{cite web|url=http://faculty.washington.edu/jbs/itrans/history.htm|title=Some Lessons from the History of Personal Rapid Transit (PRT)|publisher=University of Washington|accessdate=August 25, 2010}} The PRT cars are painted in the school colors (blue with gold trim) and feature the University name and logo on the front. Inside, the seats are light beige [[fiberglass]] and the carpeting is blue. Each car has eight seats with an overall capacity of 20 people, including standing room. The [[National Society of Professional Engineers]] named the [[Morgantown Personal Rapid Transit|WVU PRT]] one of the top 10 engineering achievements of 1972, and in 1997 ''[[The New Electric Railway Journal]]'' picked the WVU PRT as the best [[people mover]] in North America (for 1996)."Rating the Rails" (annual performance-ratings feature by transit [[Mode of transport|mode]]), ''[[The New Electric Railway Journal]]'', Spring 1997, p. 30. In 2006 the [[U.S. Department of Transportation]] and [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] dubbed WVU one of the best workplaces for commuters.[http://www.nis.wvu.edu/2006/workplace_award.htm "WVU Named One of 'Best Workplaces' for Commuters by EPA, DOT] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630142417/http://www.nis.wvu.edu/2006/workplace_award.htm |date=June 30, 2007 }} Each autumn, during Mountaineer Week celebrations, a special PRT car is placed in front of the [[Mountainlair]] [[student activity center|student union]] where groups of students participate in the "PRT Cram" with the objective of squeezing in as many people as possible. A record of 97 was set in 2000.{{cite news|first=Billy|last=Wolfe|title=PRT Cram|date=November 1, 2005|url=http://www.da.wvu.edu/show_article.php?&story_id=19842|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071111223745/http://www.da.wvu.edu/show_article.php?&story_id=19842|dead-url=yes|archive-date=November 11, 2007|work=The Daily Athenaeum|pages=|accessdate=November 6, 2007|language=}} Buses and shuttles operated by the university can be used (during limited hours) in addition to the community's Mountain Line, which operates every day into the early morning. Students can use their Mountaineer Card to ride the Mountain Line bus for free. The Health Science Center also operates a shuttle service to help students, visitors and patients to get to and from the Health Science Center campus. Many non-University, private student housing communities in the area also operate a shuttle to campus/town and back to the housing community. ===Libraries=== [[File:Downtown library.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Wise Library on the downtown campus is West Virginia University's main library.]] The [[West Virginia University Libraries]] encompass eight libraries and the WVU Press, including the Downtown Campus Library, Evansdale Library, Health Sciences Library (Morgantown), Law Library, Health Sciences Library (Charleston), the Mary F. Shipper Library at Potomac State College in Keyser, the Vining Library at the WVU Institute of Technology in Montgomery, and the [[West Virginia and Regional History Center]] (the world's largest collection of West Virginia-related research material), is in the Wise Library on the Downtown Campus.{{cite web|title=About the WVU Libraries|url=https://lib.wvu.edu/about/|website=West Virginia University Libraries|publisher=West Virginia University Libraries|accessdate=January 13, 2016}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Collections include the Appalachian Collection, Digital Collections, Government Documents, Map Collection, Myers Collection, Patent and Trademarks, Rare Books Collections, and Theses and Dissertations. West Virginia University libraries contain nearly 1.5 million printed volumes, 2.3 million microforms, more than 10,000 electronic journals, and computers with high speed Internet access. The Evansdale Library supports the academic programs and research centered on the Evansdale Campus. The library holds materials in the disciplines of agriculture, art, computer science, education, engineering, forestry, landscape architecture, mineral resources, music, physical education, and theater.{{cite web|title=Evansdale Library|url=https://lib.wvu.edu/evansdale/|website=West Virginia University Libraries|publisher=West Virginia University Libraries|accessdate=January 13, 2016}} In addition to the collections, Evansdale Library is home to da Vinci's Cafe,{{cite web|title=West Virginia University Dining Services|url=http://diningservices.wvu.edu/locations/coffee-shops/da-vinci-s|website=Da Vinci's|publisher=West Virginia University Dining Services|accessdate=January 13, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160127133937/http://diningservices.wvu.edu/locations/coffee-shops/da-vinci-s|archivedate=January 27, 2016|df=mdy-all}} an Information Technology Services Big Prints! poster printing lab,{{cite web |title=Big Prints! |url=http://it.wvu.edu/services/labs/printing/bigprints |website=West Virginia University Information Technology Services |publisher=West Virginia University Information Technology Services |accessdate=January 13, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160127123210/http://it.wvu.edu/services/labs/printing/bigprints |archive-date=January 27, 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} and the Academic Innovation Teaching and Learning Commons Sandbox.{{cite web|title=Sandbox|url=http://tlcommons.wvu.edu/Sandbox/|website=West Virginia University Teaching and Learning Commons |publisher=West Virginia University Teaching and Learning Commons|accessdate=January 13, 2016}} The university co-publishes the ''[[Labor Studies Journal]]'' with the [[United Association for Labor Education]]. ===Core Arboretum=== The '''Core Arboretum''' is a 91-acre (37 ha) arboretum owned by West Virginia University and on Monongahela Boulevard in Morgantown, West Virginia. It is open to the public daily without charge.http://arboretum.wvu.edu The Arboretum's history began in 1948 when the university acquired its site. Professor Earl Lemley Core (1902-1984), chairman of the Biology Department, then convinced President Irvin Stewart to set the property aside for the study of biology and botany. In 1975 the Arboretum was named in Core's honor. The Arboretum is now managed by the WVU Department of Biology, and consists of mostly old-growth forest on steep hillside and Monongahela River flood plain. It includes densely wooded areas with 3.5 miles (5.6 km) of walking trails, as well as 3 acres (12,000 m2) of lawn planted with specimen trees. The Arboretum has a variety of natural habitats in which several hundred species of native WV trees, shrubs, and herbaceous plants may be found. Some of the large trees are likely over 200 years old. The Arboretum is well known as a superb site to see spring ephemeral wildflowers from late March to early May. Varied habitats and riverside location also make the area an excellent site to observe birds and animals. ===Campus safety=== WVU's campus has been ranked one of the safest in the country by [[Reader's Digest]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rd.com/images/content/2008/0802/College-Safety-Survey-Results.pdf|title=College Safety Survey Results|publisher=Reader's Digest|accessdate=August 12, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111103133910/http://www.rd.com/images/content/2008/0802/College-Safety-Survey-Results.pdf|archivedate=November 3, 2011|df=}} The study was largely based on the safety of dorm facilities, emergency preparedness, and security/police staff. The university created WVU Alert, a text-based alert system for quickly disseminating emergency situations to faculty, staff and students.{{cite web|url=http://emergency.wvu.edu |title=WVU Emergency Information|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=August 12, 2010}} WVU also uses LiveSafe, a smart phone application which enables users to anonymously report crimes or safety concerns, or to use the walk safe feature which allows the user to invite a friend to monitor their location while they walk.http://www.thedaonline.com/opinion/article_119c6d00-65a6-11e6-a414-8ba9c6d6f12e.html Additionally, there are 37, easily accessible, blue-lit towers housing emergency phones across the WVU campuses that automatically dial 911 in the event of an emergency.{{cite web|url=http://police.wvu.edu/home/clery_report|title=WVU Police|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=August 12, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100622010014/http://police.wvu.edu/home/clery_report|archivedate=June 22, 2010|df=mdy-all}} The West Virginia University Police Department (UPD) is the largest campus police department in the state and the only campus law enforcement agency in the state, and one of a few in the region, to be awarded accreditation by The International Association of Campus Law Enforcement Administrators.{{cite web|url=http://wvutoday.wvu.edu/n/2013/02/12/wvu-police-department-awarded-international-association-of-campus-law-enforcement-administrators-accreditation|title=WVU Police department awarded International Association of Campus Law Enforcement Administrators Accreditation|work=WVUToday|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} Additionally, the department has also been ranked in Security Magazine's Top 500 picks in the security industry, placing 17th among higher education institutions in the rankings.{{cite web|url=http://wvutoday.wvu.edu/n/2013/11/25/wvu-police-department-receives-recognition-for-security-safety-programs|title=WVU Police Department receives recognition for security, safety programs|work=WVUToday|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} The UPD has a sworn officer operations division, a central communication unit, a student cadet unit, investigations, K-9 teams and other support services. Officers have the same authority and powers as the city and county police officers. ==Campus life== ===Events=== FallFest welcomes students to the university by providing an evening of entertainment and musical performances traditionally held during the first week of the fall semester and traditionally at the [[Mountainlair| Mountainlair Student Union]].{{cite web|url=http://wvutoday.wvu.edu/n/2008/08/14/7034|title=Daughtry to headline WVU FallFest 2008|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate= August 12, 2010}} The event began in 1995 as a safe alternative to partying and has become one of the largest University-sponsored events, typically drawing crowds of 15,000 or more.{{cite web|url=http://wboy.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=42748|title=WVU hosts annual back to school bash at the Mountainlair|publisher=WBOY|accessdate=August 12, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100225013221/http://wboy.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=42748|archivedate=February 25, 2010|df=mdy-all}} The celebration has been highlighted by a series of evening concerts by renowned artists. A dance party, film festival, comedy show, and several indoor musical performances are also featured. Mountaineer Week is a celebration of WVU tradition and [[Appalachia| Appalachian heritage]] that began in 1947.{{cite web |url=http://mountaineerweek.wvu.edu|title=WVU Mountaineer Week|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate= August 12, 2010}} Festivities have expanded to include competitions among WVU students, designed to honor school and state pride. A beard-growing competition introduced in 1949 has continued throughout the event's history. Participants must shave before the panel of judges that also chooses the winner at the end of the competition.{{cite web|url=http://wboy.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=70123|title=WVU's Beard Growing Contest|publisher=WBOY|accessdate=August 12, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724224834/http://wboy.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=70123|archivedate=July 24, 2011|df=mdy-all}} The Mr. and Ms. Mountaineer competition has been included in Mountaineer Week since 1962, honoring one male and one female student who show outstanding school spirit, academic excellence, and extracurricular involvement. The annual PRT Cram features the unique [[Morgantown Personal Rapid Transit|PRT system]], where students compete to fit the maximum number of riders on a special-model PRT car with the windows removed. The record was set in 2000, when 97 students fit inside one PRT car. Mountaineer Idol, a University version of the hit show [[American Idol]], is a relatively new event that begins during Mountaineer Week in September and extends through November. Any WVU student is eligible to enter the competition, which is scored by a panel of guest judges throughout the fall semester. The Lighting of Woodburn Hall is an annual University ceremony held in early December to light historic Woodburn Hall for the holiday season. The event began in 1987 and is open to the public. Christmas carols are typically sung, and donations are taken at the event to support community organizations. Patients from [[West Virginia University Hospitals|WVU's Children's hospital]] are often selected to light the Hall.{{cite web|url=http://wboytv.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=47818|title=WVU Lights Historic Woodburn Hall|publisher=WBOY|accessdate=August 12, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110902004931/http://wboytv.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=47818|archivedate=September 2, 2011|df=mdy-all}} Fall Family Weekend is an opportunity for students' family members to experience WVU campus life by attending classes, athletic events, college presentations, and student events such as WVU "Up All Night". Tours of the campus facilities are offered by individual colleges and organizations, including tours of the PRT.{{cite web|url=http://parentsclub.wvu.edu/r/download/40479|title=Mountaineer Parents Club Fall 2009|publisher=WVU Mountaineer Parents Club|accessdate=August 12, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100610112258/http://parentsclub.wvu.edu/r/download/40479|archive-date=June 10, 2010|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Homecoming weekend activities include the Alumni Band-led homecoming parade through downtown Morgantown, crowning of the royalty, and a football game with a performance by the WVU Alumni band. Student organizations participate in the parade by designing floats. Receptions are held by colleges, student groups, and the alumni center.{{cite web|url=http://homecoming.wvu.edu/|title=WVU homecoming|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate= August 12, 2010}} Greek Week is held during the spring semester, providing a venue for competition between Greek organizations. Highlights include airband events, where organizations compete in [[cheerleading]] and dance routines, and sports competitions on the Mountainlair recreational field. The competitions strive to highlight WVU's student spirit and present a positive image of the fraternities and sororities.{{cite web|url=http://www.wvufraternityrecruitment.org|title=WVU Fraternity Recruitment|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=August 11, 2010}} ===Recreation=== [[File:WVUMountainLair.jpg|thumb|200px|left|[[Mountainlair|The Mountainlair Student Union]] on WVU's downtown campus]] [[Mountainlair|The Mountainlair Student Union]], commonly called "the Lair" by students, is the three-floor [[student activity center|student union]] building at WVU. The building dates to 1968 and replaced an earlier structure built in 1948.{{cite journal|last=Zeller|first=Karen|date=Summer 1998|title=Mountainlair Turns 50|journal=West Virginia University Alumni Magazine.|publisher=West Virginia University|volume=21|issue=2|url=http://www.ia.wvu.edu/~magazine/sum98/mountain.html|accessdate=November 12, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828011657/http://www.ia.wvu.edu/~magazine/sum98/mountain.html|archivedate=August 28, 2008|df=}} The student union offers many recreational opportunities to students including a [[movie theater]], [[bowling alley]], [[pool hall]], [[ballroom]]s, [[Video arcade|video game arcade]], a cafeteria style restaurant, and a collection of fast food restaurants.{{cite web|url=http://mountainlair.wvu.edu|title=The Lair|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=August 12, 2010}} [[Mountainlair#WVU "Up All Night"|WVU "Up All Night"]] is a program designed to provide a safe environment for WVU students to socialize during weekends. The Mountainlair has hosted "Up All Night" every Thursday through Saturday during the fall and spring semesters since 1998. The university provides free food and beverages, and entertainment such as movie screenings at the Gluck Theater, [[laser tag]], game shows, astro bowling, comedy caravans, and casino night. The program has garnered attention from other universities, and WVU administration have been asked to speak about its success at national conferences. Administrators estimate the program's cost at $350,000 annually. [[File:WVU Student Rec Center.png|thumb|350px|right|The WVU student recreation center on the Evansdale campus]] The Student Recreation Center is a {{convert|177000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} recreation facility that opened before the 2001 academic year with an initial construction cost of $34 million. The facility offers a six-lane swimming pool, 20‑seat Jacuzzi, {{convert|17000|sqft|m2}} of cardio and free-weight equipment, an elevated running track, basketball courts, volleyball and badminton courts, glass squash and racquetball courts, and a {{convert|50|ft|m|adj=on}} climbing wall.{{cite web|url=http://studentreccenter.wvu.edu/about_the_rec_center|title=WVU Recreation Center|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=August 12, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100818165808/http://studentreccenter.wvu.edu/about_the_rec_center|archive-date=August 18, 2010|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The center also offers a variety of wellness programs, personal training, child care services, exercise classes, and intramural activities. The Mountaineer Adventure Program (MAP) offers several activities including Adventure WV, Challenge Course, and International Trips. Adventure WV is focused on providing guidance to freshmen and sophomores through various outdoor orientation expeditions. The Challenge Course program uses a recreational facility designed to teach teamwork and problem solving skills through physical interaction. International Trips offers worldwide recreational opportunities to places like [[Fiji]] and [[Peru]], as well as study abroad credit courses.{{cite web|url=http://mountaineeradventureprogram.wvu.edu/|title=WVU Mountaineer Adventure Program|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=August 12, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100626045656/http://mountaineeradventureprogram.wvu.edu/|archive-date=June 26, 2010|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Several of the MAP programs provide University-accepted credit hours. The Outdoor Recreation Center, a division of the Student Recreation Center, helps students find recreational activities locally and in other parts of West Virginia. The center sponsors some trips, including whitewater rafting on the [[Cheat River]] and hiking in the [[Monongahela National Forest]]. Students can take advantage of [[Environment of West Virginia|West Virginia's natural wilderness]] by renting outdoor recreational equipment for [[hiking]], [[camping]], [[climbing]], [[fishing]], [[biking]], [[skiing]], and [[rafting|whitewater rafting]], all of which is available with minimal travel time. WVU's main campus is next to the [[Monongahela River]] along which runs the Caperton Trail, also known as the "Rail Trail", a {{convert|10|mi|km|adj=on}} paved path for walking, running, or biking.{{cite web|url=http://www.montrails.org/maps.shtml|title=Mon River Trails Conservatory|publisher=Monongalia County|accessdate=August 12, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819110159/http://www.montrails.org/maps.shtml|archivedate=August 19, 2010|df=mdy-all}} Other connecting trails total {{convert|43|mi|km}} in additional length, extending from the [[Pennsylvania]] border to [[Prickett's Fort State Park]]. Many student groups take day trips to the nearby [[Coopers Rock State Forest]], which is less than {{convert|15|mi|km}} from WVU's campus.{{cite web|url=http://www.coopersrockstateforest.com/|title=Coopers Rock State Forest|publisher=WV State Parks|accessdate=August 12, 2010}} ===Student organizations=== West Virginia University offers more than 400 student-run organizations and clubs. Many of the organizations are associated with academia, religion, culture, military service, politics, recreation, or sports.{{cite web|url=http://studentactivities.wvu.edu|title=WVU Office of Student Activities|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=November 27, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141128151531/http://studentactivities.wvu.edu/|archive-date=November 28, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} New student groups may be formed by submitting a constitution and petition to become recognized as a student organization. ====Student Government Association==== The Student Government Association (SGA) serves as representatives for the student body and as a liaison to the university administration and officials. SGA members represent student interests in university affairs, enacting resolutions and policies related to student and campus life at WVU. The organization leadership is composed of the President and Vice President acting as an executive body. The President of the Student Body also serves as a full voting member of the university's Board of Governors. For the 2017-2018 academic year, the Student Body President and Vice President are Blake Humphrey and Shannon Smith, respectively.{{cite web|title=President and Vice President|url=http://sga.wvu.edu/executive-branch/president-and-vice-president|website=Student Government Association}} Other positions include the Attorney General, Treasurer, Communications Director, and Elections Chair. The 35-member Student Assembly has at-large Student Senators and College Representatives which comprise the legislative branch of SGA. All leadership positions are selected from an open, campus-wide election every spring semester. SGA holds weekly meetings during the Fall and Spring semesters which are open to the public.{{cite web|url=http://sga.wvu.edu|title=WVU Student Government Association|publisher=West Virginia University|accessdate=August 11, 2010}} ====Fraternities and sororities==== [[File:greek-games.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Greek Games on [[Mountainlair]] Plaza during WVU's annual Greek Week]] WVU Greek fraternities are [[Alpha Epsilon Pi]], [[Alpha Gamma Rho]], [[Kappa Alpha Order]], [[Lambda Chi Alpha]], [[Phi Delta Theta]], [[Phi Kappa Psi]], [[Pi Kappa Phi]], [[Sigma Alpha Epsilon]], [[Sigma Nu]], [[Sigma Phi Epsilon]] and [[Theta Chi]]. Greek sororities are [[Alpha Omicron Pi]], [[Alpha Phi]], [[Alpha Xi Delta]], [[Chi Omega]], [[Delta Gamma]], [[Kappa Kappa Gamma]], [[Pi Beta Phi]], and [[Sigma Kappa]][[Phi Beta Sigma]], [[Zeta Phi Beta]].https://studentorgs.wvu.edu/ ===Student media=== '''''The [[Daily Athenaeum]]''''', nicknamed ''the DA'', is the 9th-largest newspaper in West Virginia.{{cite web|url=http://www.da.wvu.edu/new/print_edition/rate_card/rate_card_07_08.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080515112542/http://www.da.wvu.edu/new/print_edition/rate_card/rate_card_07_08.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=May 15, 2008|title=Daily Athenaeum 2007–2008 Rate Card|publisher=West Virginia University DA|accessdate=August 11, 2010}} Offered free on campus, it generates income through advertisements and student fees. The paper began in 1887 as a weekly [[literary magazine]], with writing, editing and production taken over by the newly formed School of Journalism in the 1920s. In 1970, the paper split from the School of Journalism and became an independent campus entity governed by the Student Publications Board. ''The DA'' was voted as the ''[[Princeton Review]]'''s 10th-best college newspaper in the United States in 2005, 15th in 2006, and 8th in 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.princetonreview.com|title=Princeton Review Homepage|publisher=Princeton|accessdate=August 11, 2010}} [[WWVU-FM]], called '''''U92''''' or The Moose, plays new music, talk shows, and newscasts. On the air since 1982, U92 can be heard in the Morgantown area at 91.7 FM and also streams live on the internet. In 2007 the station was one of four college radio stations nominated for College Music Journal's Station of the Year Award.{{cite web|url=http://prod1.cmj.com/articles/display_article.php?id=49047299|title=College Music Journal Press Release|publisher=College Music Journal|accessdate=September 30, 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011182911/http://prod1.cmj.com/articles/display_article.php?id=49047299|archive-date=October 11, 2007|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} In 2015 CMJ awarded the station with three awards including Station of the Year.{{cite web|url=https://www.cmj.com/2015-cmj-college-radio-award-winners|title=Here Are the 2015 College Radio Award Winners|access-date=December 7, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208233414/https://www.cmj.com/2015-cmj-college-radio-award-winners/|archive-date=December 8, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ''The Mountaineer Jeffersonian'' was a news, economic, and political journal founded by WVU students.
